{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>You need to tape something, but you can't find the edge of the roll. This problem is unique to our time, and it can be infuriating. Once you have exhausted the traditional spin-the-roll-and-hunt-for-the-edge technique, you may feel frustrated and disheartened. Do not give up! Unravel the following methods and find your edge. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Using Your Senses\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-Your-Senses\">Using Your Senses</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Look closely. Turn the roll slowly in your hands, and carefully examine every inch of the circumference. The edge should look like a thin, almost invisible ridge that runs straight across the width of the tape. It may be slightly darker than the rest of the roll, and it may blend in almost perfectly. If you don't find it on the first pass, try again.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If the tape is patterned, look for the flaw or break in the continuous pattern. On a roll of zebra-print duct tape, for instance, look carefully for a point where the stripes do not entirely match up.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Consider that the edge might not be completely straight. If the roll of tape has been treated roughly, the \"edge\" might be jagged, patchy, or even extremely long. Tape-roll edges have been known to run all the way around the roll at an angle, diminishing very gradually until they taper off.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Run your finger around the roll. Use your fingertip for heightened sensation, or use your fingernail for the sake of precision. Slip your finger around the roll and feel for bumps and ridges. The edge should feel like a slightly raised ridge in the tape. If the lip is large enough, your finger will catch slightly. If you think you've identified the edge by looking closely, use your finger for a closer inspection.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you have very short fingernails, try running the edge of a knife around the rim of the roll. You might also use a toothpick, a paperclip, a key – anything that allows you the sensation and precision to feel a slight ridge in the surface of the tape. Be careful not to press too hard and puncture the tape.</li> \n    <li>If you don't feel anything on the first pass, try going around in the opposite direction.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Once you find the edge of the roll, peel it up carefully. Pick at a corner until you can hold it between your thumb and forefinger. After you manage to get a corner up with your fingernail, use your finger or thumb to roll up the edge diagonally from the corner. Pull the edge until you can hold the full width of the tape. The oils from your hands will keep the rolled edge from sticking back down.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Using a Tracer\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-a-Tracer\">Using a Tracer</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Use flour or chalk as a tracer. If your tape is dark-colored, you can use use a light-colored, contrasting \"tracer\" to reveal the edge of the roll. The basic idea here is to rub a clumpy white material—flour, chalk, and baking powder are good choices—around the outside of the tape roll until the tracer sticks to the hidden edge. If you are using a thicker tape, such as duct tape, this effect may be more apparent than if you are using a thinner tape.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Put a bit of flour or chalk dust into a cup or small container. Any material will do, as long as it clumps together and the color contrasts with the color of the tape.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Dip your finger into the cup or container. It may help to wet your finger, slightly, beforehand.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don't want to use your finger, you can also dip the roll of tape directly into the flour or chalk dust. Be sure to immerse it thoroughly. There is a chance that the flour will stick to the edge of the roll, revealing your goal!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Run your floured finger around the circumference of the tape. Go slowly and methodically in one direction, then the other. This way, your finger is more likely to catch the edge of the roll. Make sure not to skip over any sections, or you might miss it! The edge should become quickly apparent: the flour will catch along the crack, forming a white line.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Wipe your finger clean once you've found the edge. Try not to get any flour or chalk onto the sticky side of the tape.{largeimage|use tape as required Step 5.jpg}}\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Use a pencil as a tracer. If your tape is light in color, try running the flat side of a pencil point around the roll. The dark-grey graphite from the pencil will serve a similar function to the flour. The pencil should bump up very slightly when it hits the edge of the roll, and you will be able to see the break in the graphite line.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Preventing the Problem\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Preventing-the-Problem\">Preventing the Problem</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Cut a V-shape into the tape roll. Use a sharp knife or a pair of scissors to cut a small wedge out of the entire roll of tape – from the outermost edge to the innermost end. This way, you'll tear the tape off in the same spot every time, and you may have less trouble finding the edge in the future!<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 11 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Mark the end of the roll with a toothpick. When you are done using a roll of tape for the time being, stick a toothpick underneath the adhesive about a half-inch from the edge. This way, when you return to use the tape again, you will be able to easily identify where to begin. This method is especially useful for clear packing tape.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>In theory, you can use almost anything to mark the end of the roll: paper, a paperclip, a twig, a card. Use anything that isn't too bulky and sticks cleanly to the edge of the tape. Improvise a solution using the materials you have lying around your home or office.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Fold the edge of the tape back on itself. Fold the sticky end of the tape back into the roll—not far, just a centimeter or so—to make a \"pull tab\" for the next time you use the tape. You can fold the tape directly in, or you can fold at a 45-degree angle for a triangular fold.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Use a tape dispenser. Consider buying a dedicated tape dispenser. These devices usually include a spool (which you can continually refill with new rolls of tape) and a serrated tape-cutting edge. When you stretch the tape over the serrated edge, it slices cleanly and naturally. The edge of the tape sticks there until you need it next.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Consider buying a \"tape gun\" for packing tape. This device is a convenient, handheld version of the standard tape dispenser. Run the tape gun along the surface of a box, and you will seal the box without losing the edge of the roll.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>You can find tape dispensers online or at office-supply stores. Be aware that many standard tape dispensers are designed for use with Scotch tape</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Buy striped or patterned tape. It is easier to find the edge of a roll of patterned tape, as you can visually parse out the breaks in the pattern. If you consistently have trouble finding the edge of a roll of tape, consider making a habit of buying patterned tape for the sake of convenience.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 15 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Buy sticky tape with non-stick sides. Some tape is designed with black lines on the sides to denote where the adhesive ends. This way, you will not need to find the edge of the roll – you'll be able to pull it up at any point! Look for this specialty tape online or in large office-supply stores.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Find the Edge of a Roll of Tape Step 16 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cf/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Don't put yourself through this frustration again. Once you've found the tape, be sure to take preventative measures—a tape dispenser, a toothpick, a V-cut—to ensure that you always know where to find the edge of your tape.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Tape</li> \n  <li>Flour, chalk, or pencil</li> \n  <li>Persistence</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Refill-a-Tape-Dispenser\" title=\"Refill a Tape Dispenser\">Refill a Tape Dispenser</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-a-Stapler\" title=\"Use a Stapler\">Use a Stapler</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\"   <li id=\"_note-6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape#_ref-6\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2545304/Wrapping-gifts-just-got-easier-Sticky-tape-non-stick-sides-takes-stress-finding-annoying-invisible-edge.html\">http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2545304/Wrapping-gifts-just-got-easier-Sticky-tape-non-stick-sides-takes-stress-finding-annoying-invisible-edge.html</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 12 Mar 2022 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"89f3716d1f7225a8a42148ea05c68fc0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn12@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-14-54-993_bf2a715c9bf87428.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":58508,"destBytes":29690,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn12@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-14-54-993_bf2a715c9bf87428.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn79@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-12-885_e8868b872ba7c091.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn91@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-12-432_9cf65a00b08764a8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn42@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-28-504_8db5510dbf32d221.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn96@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-13-416_e02363f1d67c52b4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn79@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-09-138_c9c813fd0c1d3bdc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn71@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-12-382_f8ef2e34110c8a10.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn61@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-12-981_72c6245391da645c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn45@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-12-319_6e66063cc8b7cbab.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn44@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-13-719_837413aca4a3815b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8b/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-11-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn46@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-09-799_abf254530b201756.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn20@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-09-202_6bcda30dcc67d893.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-14-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn2@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-10-169_ad67e04d2bd0f491.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-15-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn20@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-11-755_65221e3493eeb06e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cf/Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid375705-v4-728px-Find-the-Edge-of-a-Roll-of-Tape-Step-16-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn94@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-11-088_8e113a7b4b03cac1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693958},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Clean Cloudy Glasses","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Glasses made cloudy by grime, damage, or dirtiness can reduce your vision to next-to-nothing. While there is little you can do to restore scratched lenses to a clearer state, there are tricks you can use to clean your cloudy glasses efficiently while preserving the lenses.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> With the right supplies on hand and the knowledge of proper lens cleaning, soon you'll be seeing blue skies where once you only saw cloudy lenses. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Cleaning Cloudy Lenses\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cleaning-Cloudy-Lenses\">Cleaning Cloudy Lenses</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Acquire a soft, clean cloth. In most cases, when you purchase your glasses from an optometrist, optical office, or eye boutique, you will also receive a microfiber cloth intended for cleaning your lenses. This cloth is ideal for cleaning smudges and cloudiness.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Cloudy Glasses Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you've lost or misplaced your microfiber cloth, find a soft, clean substitute cloth. Cotton, so long as it's clean, should be suitable.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup> It is important to use fabric that is not treated with fabric softener as that can cause streaks on the lenses.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>You should avoid using: coarse fabrics, like wool and certain synthetic fabrics, facial tissue, or toilet paper, as these will cause tiny scratches to form on your lenses over time.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make use of glasses cleaner. These solutions are specially formulated to cut through dirtiness without doing harm to your lenses or coatings that may be on your lenses. Spritz a moderate amount of the cleaner onto your lens and wipe it clean with your soft, clean cloth.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Cloudy Glasses Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Do not use your saliva to clean your lenses. Saliva won't clean especially well and is unhygienic.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Clean with dish soap and warm water. If you don't happen to have glasses cleaner on hand, you can use a drop of dish soap and warm water to cut through grime and leave your lenses pristine.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup> Use your fingers and carefully spread the soap over the surface of your lenses. Rinse the lenses clean of soap with warm water, and you're ready to move on.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Wipe your glasses with your soft cloth. After applying your cleaning solution, you can take your soft cloth and wipe your lenses dry in gentle, circular motions. You should try not to use scrubbing motions, which can lead to lens damage over time.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Inspect lenses for stubborn stains. Depending on just how dirty your glasses really are, you may need another application of cleaner before you lenses become fully clean. After using your cleaner or dish soap and hot water, wipe your lenses with your soft cloth.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Cloudy Glasses Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Break up nose pad residue. Oil and dust can collect in the nook between your nose pads and lenses, creating a cloudy film in the area close to your nose. By using a soft bristle toothbrush, dish soap, and warm water, you can bust up this grimy buildup, though you should be careful not to scrub your lenses with the toothbrush.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Fill a basin or container with warm water and soap.</li> \n    <li>Dip your cleaning toothbrush into the solution and swish it around.</li> \n    <li>Gently scrub at the metal arm that connects your nose pad to your glasses frames.</li> \n    <li>Swish your toothbrush in your water/soap solution to remove dirt and gunk that accumulates on your brush.</li> \n    <li>Rinse your glasses under warm water.</li> \n    <li>Check for remaining grime and buildup and repeat scrubbing until fully clean.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Making Homemade Lens Cleaner\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-Homemade-Lens-Cleaner\">Making Homemade Lens Cleaner</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Gather your supplies. Homemade lens cleaner won't damage the coating on your lenses like some other cleaning agents might, but you can count on it to cut through the clouds and smudges on your glasses. This is also a cheap alternative to ready-made eyeglass cleaner in the event that you ran out or weren't given any at your previous visit to the eye doctor. To make your own lens cleaner, you will need:\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Cloudy Glasses Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Dish soap</li> \n    <li>Isopropyl alcohol (or witch hazel)</li> \n    <li>Measuring cup</li> \n    <li>Microfiber cloth</li> \n    <li>Small spray bottle</li> \n    <li>Water<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Prepare your supplies. You should clean your spray bottle and measuring cup before mixing your glass cleaning solution. This is because any dirt or dust left behind in these can contaminate your homemade lens cleaner. This is especially important if you are using a general purpose spray bottle that might have previously contained other household cleaners.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Cloudy Glasses Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Mix the liquids of your cleaner in equal parts. Now that your measuring cup and spray bottle are clean, you should measure your water and isopropyl alcohol in a 1-to-1 ratio and add each to your spray bottle.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup> Swirl your bottle gently to mix the solution.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, you may want to combine 1 ounce of water with 1 ounce of isopropyl alcohol in your spray bottle.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add your dish soap.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup> For this recipe, you will only need a very small amount of dish soap to give your lens cleaner some added smudge-fighting action. Put one drop of dish soap into your mixed solution of water and isopropyl alcohol. Cap your bottle and swirl its contents gently to infuse the solution with soap.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Apply your cleaner and wipe away the clouds. Spray a moderate amount of your lens cleaner onto each lens. Now you can take your clean microfiber cloth and wipe away all the gunk that has accumulated on your glasses.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don't have a microfiber cloth intended for glasses, clean cotton should do the job.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Preventing Cloudiness\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Preventing-Cloudiness\">Preventing Cloudiness</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Use a clean, soft cloth always. The microfiber cloth that may have come with your glasses is ideal for cleaning your lenses, but even this can become dirty over time. Using a cloth that has dust on it will cause your lenses to develop small pits and scratches over time, creating cloudiness. To avoid this, only clean your glasses with a clean, soft cloth.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Cloudy Glasses Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Protect your lens cloth from the elements. The more dust and grime that is on your lens cleaning cloth, the more damage you will do to your lenses over time. Every time you dry, wipe, or polish your lenses, you will be scraping these particles against your glasses.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Cloudy Glasses Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To keep your lens cloth cleanest, you may want to hold it in a glasses case that you carry with you throughout the day. You might also put this cloth in a plastic baggie or other container and tuck it away in a backpack or satchel.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wash your lens cleaning cloth. Depending on the cloth your are using, cleaning procedure can vary. A soft cotton piece of fabric can be washed normally, but you should follow the directions that came with your cloth. For cleaning a microfiber cloth, you should:\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Cloudy Glasses Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Separate it with like-fabric items.</li> \n    <li>Add a small amount of liquid detergent to your washing machine. Do not use fabric softener — this remains on the cloth and can leave streaks when using it on lenses.</li> \n    <li>Set your washing machine to cold.</li> \n    <li>Insert your microfiber cloth and like-cloth items into the wash.</li> \n    <li>Air dry or use a dryer on a low/no-heat setting.<sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Clean your lenses regularly. Over the course of a day your glasses will normally collect dust, dirt, and oil from your face and hands. By cleaning your lenses regularly with glass cleaner or warm water and a drop of dish soap, you can cut down on the overall daily cloudiness you may experience.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Cloudy Glasses Step 15 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/da/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Keep your glasses in a case when you're not wearing them. This will keep dust from settling on the glasses and protect them from harm if they are knocked over. Instead of placing your glasses on your bedside table at night, for instance, place them in their case and then put that on your bedside table. This will also protect your glasses from getting broken or damaged if you knock them over when not in use.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean Cloudy Glasses Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-16.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Many anti-glare coatings have a treatment that repels dust, oil, and water. This can significantly reduce the amount of cleaning that you need to do on your glasses.</li>\n </ul> \n <p><br /> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Be gentle while cleaning, the last thing you want is a permanently scratched lens, broken nose pad, or bent frame.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Cleaning Cloudy Lenses\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cleaning-Cloudy-Lenses_2\">Cleaning Cloudy Lenses</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Dish soap (optional)</li> \n  <li>Glasses</li> \n  <li>Glasses cleaning solution (optional)</li> \n  <li>Microfiber cloth (or clean, soft cloth)</li> \n  <li>Toothbrush (optional)</li>\n </ul> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Making Homemade Lens Cleaner\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-Homemade-Lens-Cleaner_2\">Making Homemade Lens Cleaner</span></h3> \n <ul>\n  <li>Dish soap</li> \n  <li>Isopropyl alcohol (or witch hazel)</li> \n  <li>Measuring cup</li> \n  <li>Microfiber cloth (or clean, soft cloth)</li> \n  <li>Small spray bottle</li> \n  <li>Water</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Eyeglasses\" title=\"Clean Eyeglasses\">Clean Eyeglasses</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-Cloudy-Glasses&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 11 Mar 2022 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"503506385dab47b677c06b9da3a15435","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn8@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-14-54-869_a31ac3978366491d.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":46613,"destBytes":30376,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn8@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-14-54-869_a31ac3978366491d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn44@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-09-236_8ddcf36a738027ae.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn28@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-21-786_99f488693c98e4d7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d5/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn58@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-10-218_e6b6686e1d738f67.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e5/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn8@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-12-626_bee6f3301a70bb37.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn6@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-10-768_e105f51b206ec8b1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d0/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn3@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-11-988_c73a0ee2dbd8a7d2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-14-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn91@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-13-131_84ab175cc707ddc0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/da/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-15-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn69@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-10-966_92ccc81a0981088c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-16.jpg/aid1055453-v4-728px-Clean-Cloudy-Glasses-Step-16.jpg":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693972},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Make Tissue Paper Flowers","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Tissue paper flowers make great decorations and party décor. They’re eye-catching and colorful as well as inexpensive and easy to make. Choose a flower to make, such as a dahlia, rose, or hydrangea, and get started. In order to make all of these different <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Flowers\" title=\"Make Flowers\">flowers</a>, you'll need supplies such as tissue paper, scissors, floral wire, and an adhesive. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Making a Tissue Paper Dahlia\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-a-Tissue-Paper-Dahlia\">Making a Tissue Paper Dahlia</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Stack 12 sheets of tissue paper on top of each other. You can choose any color you want. Generally, it looks more realistic if you use the same color for all 12 sheets. Use the normal size of tissue paper for a larger decorative flower.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup><span id=\"fold\"></span><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re making them as decorations for a party, follow your color palette.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Fold all 12 sheets together accordion-style. Start with a fold, then follow each fold accordingly by alternating the fold direction. Crease each fold so it will hold its shape. When you’re done, the paper should look like wide stack.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><span id=\"crease\"></span><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Round the ends with scissors for more realistic petals. Use a sharp pair of scissors to round or point the ends of the stack. This will be a pretty extra touch and make your tissue paper flower look more realistic.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure your scissors are strong and sharp in order to cut through that many layers. If they’re too dull, they’ll mangle the paper and make rough cuts.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut a piece of floral wire for the stem. Fold the piece of wire in half and slip it over the center of the tissue paper, then tightly twist it closed. Trim the wire as needed or wrap it in green floral tape.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Floral wire works well and looks nice, but you can also use a pipe cleaner to make a stem.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Spread out the petals one layer at a time. Separate and spread each petal layer, pulling them toward the center of the flower one at a time. This will fluff the petals out and create a beautiful layered effect to mimic the fullness of a real flower. Leave a little space in the center of the flower.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you want to display the flower on a wall or flat surface, only separate and fluff the layers on one side. Leave the back completely flat so it can easily rest against a flat surface.</li> \n    <li>If you want to suspend the flower, such as with string from the ceiling, fluff out both sides evenly. Leave some space for the center on both sides.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Decorate with your paper flower. Arrange the flowers as decorations for parties such as garden parties, birthday parties for young girls, baby showers, and bridal showers.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-6-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Tissue Paper Flowers Step 6 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-6-Version-6.jpg/aid121781-v4-728px-Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-6-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To suspend the flowers, tie a length of monofilament to the floral wire and hang from the ceiling.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <p><br /> </p> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Crafting a Tissue Paper Rose\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Crafting-a-Tissue-Paper-Rose\">Crafting a Tissue Paper Rose</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Select one or two colors of tissue paper. If you want a simple, classic look, choose one sheet of in pink, red, or coral. For a two-toned rose, grab an additional sheet in a different shade. Some combinations that really pop are pink and ruby or orange and tangerine.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-7-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Tissue Paper Flowers Step 7 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9b/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-7-Version-6.jpg/aid121781-v4-728px-Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-7-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Cut one or two strips of tissue paper. For the main petals, cut a single strip down the length of the tissue paper. Cut another strip for an optional accent color.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Fold the two strips in half together. Place the accent color strip on top of the main strip and fold both strips in half, with the accent color inside the fold. Then accordion fold the strips together, folding in alternate directions every or so.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Use scissors to scallop one side of the folded strip. Take a sharp pair of scissors and round one of the ends of the folded strip of tissue paper--the selvage end. This will create a petal shape. When you finish, gently unfold the accordion-folded strip and lay it out, petals right side up.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Cut a piece of floral wire for a stem. Once you’ve created your stem, you can trim the floral wire as needed.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-11-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Tissue Paper Flowers Step 11 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/51/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-11-Version-6.jpg/aid121781-v4-728px-Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-11-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Place adhesive on the edge of the tissue strip. Glue dots work best for this because they’re more precise and create less mess, but you can also use hot glue or craft glue. Make sure the adhesive is close to the edge, where the stem will come in contact with the petal strip.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Wrap the tissue paper around the floral wire. Lay the floral wire stem on the adhesive, then begin wrapping the tissue paper strip tightly. Firmly the base of the flower as you wrap, gathering up any slack. Gradually loosen your wrapping to create a blooming effect.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Secure the slack at the bottom with a strip of floral tape. Wind the tape around the flower base several times, then keep wrapping diagonally down the stem. Make sure you’re wrapping the tape tightly enough to hold the tissue paper rose together.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Separate and spread out the petals. Arrange your rose’s petals by gently separating the layers and spreading them outwards. This will help fill out your flower and make it look more realistic.<br /><br /></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Making Tissue Paper Hydrangeas\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-Tissue-Paper-Hydrangeas\">Making Tissue Paper Hydrangeas</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Choose several sheets of colored tissue paper for your flower. If you want a classic hydrangea color, go for light blue, lavender, pale green, or pink. You could also select some green tissue paper if you want to make leaves.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-16-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Tissue Paper Flowers Step 16 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-16-Version-6.jpg/aid121781-v4-728px-Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-16-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Cut out 120 teardrop-shaped petals. Fold your sheets of tissue paper until they make an inch-wide stack. Then use a sharp pair of scissors to cut out a teardrop shape for the petals. You’ll need around 120 petals to fill out the flower.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can make the petals any size you want, but wide is generally a realistic size.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut and bundle 30 pieces of floral wire to make the flower’s base. Cut your wire pieces at and bundle them together neatly. Wrap the bundle with floral tape about from the top of the wire.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Spread out the wires at the top. The side wires should stick out perpendicular to the bundle, while the others should be spread out evenly.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Hot-glue the petals to the wires. Start by hot-gluing two petals to a wire and then make a small loop at the end of the wire. Hot-glue the center, then add more petals to fill out the flower and hide the loop. Continue doing this for all of the wires until the flower is complete.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also double up petals for more fullness.</li> \n    <li>Cover as much of the wire with petals as possible--add extra petals in spots where the wire peeks through.</li> \n    <li>If you made leaves, glue those to the base of the stem.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Fluff up the petals. With hydrangeas, you shouldn’t separate the petals too much, but try to separate the petals a bit and move the ends around after the glue has dried. This will make the flower appear fuller and more natural.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-21-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Tissue Paper Flowers Step 21 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-21-Version-6.jpg/aid121781-v4-728px-Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers-Step-21-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Tissue paper</li> \n  <li>Floral wire</li> \n  <li>Adhesive (such as glue dots)</li> \n  <li>Scissors</li> \n  <li>Floral tape</li> \n  <li>Hot glue gun</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Spray the tissue paper flower with perfume or put a small drop of scented oil in the middle to make a scented flower.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-Elegant-Paper-Snowflakes\" title=\"Cut Elegant Paper Snowflakes\">Cut Elegant Paper Snowflakes</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Confetti\" title=\"Make Confetti\">Make Confetti</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Fold-Paper-Flowers\" title=\"Fold Paper Flowers\">Fold Paper Flowers</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Paper-Tropical-Flowers\" title=\"Make Paper Tropical Flowers\">Make Paper Tropical Flowers</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Butterflies\" title=\"Make Tissue Paper Butterflies\">Make Tissue Paper Butterflies</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://projectnursery.com/2014/04/diy-tissue-paper-flowers/\">https://projectnursery.com/2014/04/diy-tissue-paper-flowers/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Tissue-Paper-Flowers#_ref-3\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\"
