</li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 09 Mar 2022 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"36eb50f853ea72929c713956938bc52e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn24@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-54-859_fadc74ca06de4adb.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":34907,"destBytes":31802,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn24@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-54-859_fadc74ca06de4adb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn23@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-13-669_cfee0159db33f035.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn61@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-11-046_801c7d7deb45fb82.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn50@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-09-940_2be155cd5798c97b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/aa/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn74@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-20-336_7dbd02974adf0ff7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/71/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn27@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-11-864_1e4b225ec43f5a36.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn88@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-09-822_50f579ba06355570.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/55/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn55@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-13-914_0dcbfdeb62ac49c3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn19@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-13-167_070e258c530a0561.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid68477-v4-728px-Hold-a-Door-Open-with-a-Coin-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn26@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-09-203_09502d35127cb621.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693971},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Make Bead Earrings","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bead-Earrings","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Beaded earrings might seem difficult to make, but they are really very simple if you have the right tools and materials. You can easily create a beautiful pair of beaded drop earrings to give as a gift, to match a special outfit, or to sell as part of your handmade jewelry business. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bead-Earrings&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bead-Earrings&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Making a Basic Pair of Beaded Earrings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-a-Basic-Pair-of-Beaded-Earrings\">Making a Basic Pair of Beaded Earrings</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Gather your materials. Making beaded earrings is quite easy. However, you will need to have some special materials ready before you get started. You will probably need to visit a craft store to find everything, or you can order your materials online. Before you begin, you will need:<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bead-Earrings#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-1-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bead Earrings Step 1 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid201701-v4-728px-Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-1-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Endpins (These are also known as headpins and look like a straight wire with a small button at the end.) Endpins are available in various thicknesses to accommodate different sizes of beads. Sometimes you will see the thickness mentioned by gauge (ga) on the packaging. In this case, a larger number (for example, 24 ga) indicates a thinner endpin, while a smaller number (for example, 20 ga) indicates a thicker headpin.</li> \n    <li>Beads in the colors and types of your choice</li> \n    <li>Round nose pliers</li> \n    <li>Earring hooks</li> \n    <li>Wire cutters</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add your beads. First, put a spacer bead or a bead with a smaller hole than your other beads at the bottom of the endpin, then add the beads of your choice on the endpin.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bead-Earrings#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Arrange the beads in the order you want them to create a colorful pattern.</li> \n    <li>Experiment with different colors and styles.</li> \n    <li>Use spacer beads to separate colors if desired.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Continue adding beads. Keep adding beads to the endpin until you have 1/4\" to 3/8\" (6mm to 1cm) of space remaining. It is important to leave some space so that the earrings will retain their movement and will not be stiff.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bead-Earrings#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you want your earrings to be shorter, use a pair of wire cutters to snip the headpin to the appropriate length.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a pair of round-nose pliers to bend the top of your head-pin. Bend the head pin until it is at a 90 degree angle to the beads. This will help to secure the beads in place and begin the attachment to your earring hook.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Bend the top of the endpin into a loop using the round-nose pliers. This loop allows you to add a post or wire to complete the earring at the end of the headpin with the round-nose pliers. Using the tip of the pliers as a guide, form the end of the headpin into a neat loop.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bead-Earrings#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If there is any excess wire going out from the loop, then snip it at the base of the loop using a pair of wire cutters. Make sure to wear eye protection when you do this because the wire may fly up towards your face.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add the earring hook. Next you will need to attach the earring hook to the loop. Do this before you close the loop all the way. Then, use your round nose pliers to close the loop.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bead-Earrings#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Make your second earring and enjoy! After you have created one earring, you will just need to make a second earring in the same manner, and you will have a completed pair of beaded earrings! Try them on, give them as a gift, or add them to your stock of handmade jewelry to sell.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-7-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bead Earrings Step 7 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-7-Version-4.jpg/aid201701-v4-728px-Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-7-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bead-Earrings&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Customizing Your Earrings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Customizing-Your-Earrings\">Customizing Your Earrings</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Include a central bead or pendant. Instead of making your earrings with a sequence of small beads only, you can use a larger decorative bead or a pendant as a way to make your earrings stand out more. Try putting one large, interesting bead near the bottom or center of your earrings, or attach a pendant to the bottom of your endpin.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bead Earrings Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid201701-v4-728px-Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can find endpins that have a rounded wire end, which is useful for hanging pendants from.</li> \n    <li>Unless the pendant already has a jump ring attached, you will need to get some jump rings to attach the pendant. These are small metal ring that you open and close with pliers to attach them to the wire endpin.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Experiment with wire wrapping. Wire wrapping is a jewelry making technique that can make your hand-crafted earrings look even more intricate and beautiful. You can use pliers to wire <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Wire-Wrap-Stones\" title=\"Wire Wrap Stones\">wrap large beads and stones</a>, which you can use as a pendant for earrings.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bead Earrings Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid201701-v4-728px-Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This technique takes some practice and patience to learn, so plan on doing some experimental pieces before you are ready to make earrings.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a different type of base. Endpins are the classic type of earring base that jewelers use for earrings, but you can also use other types of bases to give your beaded earrings a different design. See what types of earring bases are available at your local crafting store and do some experimentation.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bead Earrings Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid201701-v4-728px-Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For example, if you want your earrings to have more movement, then you could use some fishing line as the base for your beads instead.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bead-Earrings#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup> Or, you may be able to find some hoop earrings that are thin enough to slide your beads onto.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bead-Earrings&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bead-Earrings&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Remember to wear eye protection whenever you use wire cutters. While making beaded jewelry is quite safe compared with a lot of other crafts, a small snipped piece of wire can be propelled with a lot of force in an unpredictable direction.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bead-Earrings&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Endpins</li> \n  <li>Round-nose pliers</li> \n  <li>Wire cutters</li> \n  <li>Beads</li> \n  <li>Earring hooks</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bead-Earrings&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Beads-from-Flour-and-Water\" title=\"Make Beads from Flour and Water\">Make Beads from Flour and Water</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Pearl-Earrings\" title=\"Make Pearl Earrings\">Make Pearl Earrings</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Earrings\" title=\"Make Earrings\">Make Earrings</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bead-Earrings&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bead-Earrings&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bead-Earrings#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://inmyownstyle.com/2013/01/how-to-make-elegantly-simple-drop-earrings.html\">http://inmyownstyle.com/2013/01/how-to-make-elegantly-simple-drop-earrings.html</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bead-Earrings#_ref-2\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZwPOLdAkkgw\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZwPOLdAkkgw</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bead-Earrings#_ref-4\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://inmyownstyle.com/2013/01/how-to-make-elegantly-simple-drop-earrings.html\">http://inmyownstyle.com/2013/01/how-to-make-elegantly-simple-drop-earrings.html</a></span> </li> \n   <li \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 07 Mar 2022 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid201701-v4-728px-Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-1-Version-4.jpg","linkMd5":"b22a840ec07f43484ca744b5e7792ad6","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn21@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-14-56-724_ac91766913a7aa92.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":50886,"destBytes":34318,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5b/Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid201701-v4-728px-Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-1-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn21@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-14-56-724_ac91766913a7aa92.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d2/Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-7-Version-4.jpg/aid201701-v4-728px-Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-7-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn35@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-13-703_b95f6eabeb69f23c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ef/Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid201701-v4-728px-Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn91@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-11-533_99650362104272dd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid201701-v4-728px-Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn71@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-11-459_fbf64c29a7b283f3.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f6/Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid201701-v4-728px-Make-Bead-Earrings-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn29@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-09-816_b166fcc5b690183b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693972},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Clean a Harmonica","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Do you want to clean your harmonica? Harmonica maintenance can be a delicate matter because of how fragile the inside of the instrument is. Follow these tips to successfully clean your harmonica. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-a-Harmonica&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-a-Harmonica&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Cleaning Your Harmonica Daily\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cleaning-Your-Harmonica-Daily\">Cleaning Your Harmonica Daily</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Rinse with lukewarm water. If you have a diatonic harmonica with a plastic comb, simply run some lukewarm water through the harmonica. Placing the mouthpiece against your palm, tap it firmly to remove the water.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean a Harmonica Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Only run water through the harmonica if your comb is plastic or sealed wood. If the comb is wooden or metal, do not run water through it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Tap the harmonica after each use. Because a harmonica is played with the mouth, saliva and other contaminants get blown into the instrument by the mouth. After each use, tap the harmonica on your hand, leg, or a towel to knock out any loose saliva. This will help keep it clean and help reduce the amount of build-up in the instrument.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean a Harmonica Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/64/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try to be a dry harmonica player. This means you should try to reduce the amount of saliva that you pass into the harmonica while playing.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Let your harmonica dry after playing. Another way you can help keep your harmonica clean and rust-free is to let it dry after playing. When you place it in the case, leave the case open. This helps any moisture in the harmonica to dry instead of sitting there damp in your harmonica.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean a Harmonica Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0d/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Clean your mouth before playing. If you have eaten or drunk anything right before playing, rinse your mouth with water. Remnants of food can get blown into the harmonica, and sugar or other contaminants from non-water beverages can build up a residue in the harmonica.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean a Harmonica Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Refrain from playing right after brushing your teeth. Any residue left over from the toothpaste or mouthwash can build up.</li> \n    <li>Don't smoke while playing the harmonica. This can damage the harmonica.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-a-Harmonica&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Performing Heavy Cleaning on Your Harmonica\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Performing-Heavy-Cleaning-on-Your-Harmonica\">Performing Heavy Cleaning on Your Harmonica</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Remove the cover plates. Use an appropriate screwdriver to remove the cover plates of the harmonica. Some harmonicas use a Phillips-head screwdriver, while others use a flat head. Make sure to find a screwdriver of the appropriate size.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean a Harmonica Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Place the screws in a safe place where they won't be lost.</li> \n    <li>Spray both sides of the cover plates with alcohol and then wipe with a cloth.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove the reed plates. After removing the cover plates, use the screwdriver to remove the screws attached to the reed plates. Keep the screws in the order from which you remove them so they are placed back in the same hole as before.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean a Harmonica Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Soak the reed plates. Place the reed plates into a solution of warm water and vinegar or lemon juice. Let them soak for approximately half an hour.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean a Harmonica Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Clean the comb. While the reed plates are soaking, clean the comb. If the comb is plastic, you can clean it with soap and water. Use a soft toothbrush to brush the deposits off the comb.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup> Another option is to spray the comb with alcohol and brush it with a soft brush. You can also use something sharp to dig any build-up off the comb.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean a Harmonica Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you have a wooden comb, do not use water or soap. Just use the brush or the sharp object. If you have a metal comb, make sure to dry it thoroughly before reassembling.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Clean the reed plates. Remove the reed plates from the water. Use a soft toothbrush to brush the reed plates.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup> Do not scrub the reed plates with the toothbrush.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup> You want to gently brush the reed plates along the reeds from the rivet down. Don't brush against the reeds or snag the ends of the reeds. This can damage the reeds or mess up the notes of the harmonica.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean a Harmonica Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Never brush across the reed. Only brush in the direction of the reed.</li> \n    <li>Clean the other side of the reed plate as vigorously as you want since it has no reeds.</li> \n    <li>Then run it under warm water to rinse.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>You can also clean the reed plates with a q-tip and hydrogen peroxide.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Reassemble. Let all of the harmonica parts completely dry. Then, reassemble the harmonica.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Clean a Harmonica Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Screw the screws back in gradually. Tighten all three of them evenly before you tighten them as far as they can go.<sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Clean-a-Harmonica#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-a-Harmonica&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-a-Harmonica&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Never rub too hard.</li> \n  <li>Be careful with the harmonica.</li> \n  <li>Keep your pieces safe in a (preferably sunny) dry location while drying, especially out of reach from pets.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-a-Harmonica&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Cleaning too often may result in loss of sound.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-a-Harmonica&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-a-Harmonica\" title=\"Play a Harmonica\">Play a Harmonica</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Clean-a-Harmonica&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 13 Mar 2022 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"4d22a525d5411f74a8fe05b8fa82d5c7","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn40@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-14-56-555_b75aa715076cfd9f.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":57420,"destBytes":32528,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2b/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn40@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-14-56-555_b75aa715076cfd9f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/64/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn58@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-10-363_1f8cae5da9ba886c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0d/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn2@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-10-845_50c850c56cb2c54f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn72@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-09-609_0ff2ecd8ca6d61bc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4a/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn34@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-12-800_19a9d13b86a38982.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn16@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-12-208_58256f49135e519b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/25/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn8@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-13-552_a2c19f10940a0b0d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn15@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-11-741_86ed220f81d865ac.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn96@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-13-086_eb8660d6455be24b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid617974-v4-728px-Clean-a-Harmonica-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn70@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-09-645_ea6e97e8b4ae7994.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693954},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Grow Poppies","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Poppies are versatile, show-stopping plants that include several varieties, from the big, bold Oriental poppy, which can grow as tall as 4 feet (122cm), to the demure Alpine poppy, topping out at about 10 inches (25cm). Poppies are tough plants that can thrive in any well-draining soil, although these tips will teach you how to grow them to encourage a healthy, blooming flowerbed. Once you have flowering poppies, you will likely have enough seeds to plant new poppies year after year. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Grow-Poppies&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Grow-Poppies&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Planting the Seeds\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Planting-the-Seeds\">Planting the Seeds</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Prepare to plant in autumn or early spring, depending on your local climate. Poppy seeds require exposure to cool or cold temperatures before they will reliably sprout. As long as the winter temperatures in your area do not fall below 0ºF (-18ºC), you may plant the seeds in autumn, before the first frost. In colder climates or if convenient, plant the poppy seeds in spring, as soon as the ground thaws.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Grow-Poppies-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The temperatures that allow for autumn planting correspond to United States Plant Hardiness Zones 7 and higher.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>If the winter temperatures in your area fall below -20ºF (-29ºC), consider planting the cold-resistant Iceland poppy.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Consider planting in several stages. If you divide your poppy seeds into groups and plant each group a week or two apart, your garden will have colorful flowers for a longer period of time. You may wish to plant half in the first week or two of spring, and the other half later in the spring to see which group suits your climate and poppy variety best.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/32/Grow-Poppies-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you will be planting poppies in autumn, then you don’t need to plant in stages.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Select an area with full sun or partial shade. Generally, poppies grow best when they receive at least six hours of sunlight a day. However, if you live in a hot climate, select a spot where the poppies will be protected during the intense heat of the afternoon.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Grow-Poppies-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Purple poppies may retain a brighter, more attractive color in partial shade than in full sun.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Test soil drainage. Soil with excellent water drainage is crucial, as poppies will rot in waterlogged soil. This is especially important during winter, when soil becomes wet or frozen. Begin testing by digging a hole 4 inches (10 cm) deep. Fill the hole with water, allow it to drain completely, then fill it a second time. Time how long it takes to drain again: this should take no more than four hours at the very most, and preferably less.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Grow-Poppies-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Improve soil quality and drainage if necessary. If you cannot find a location in your yard with good drainage, try mixing the top 2 inches (5cm) of soil with compost and a little sand, or <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Construct-a-Raised-Planting-Bed\" title=\"Construct a Raised Planting Bed\">building a raised bed</a>. Perennial poppies, which are able to live for longer than one year, may require compost or a store-bought garden soil to thrive even if the existing drainage is adequate.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Grow-Poppies-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Till the soil to loosen it if necessary. Use a shovel or tiller to loosen compact soil to a depth of approximately 8 inches (20cm). Poppy seeds grow one long taproot straight downward to collect water, and may not be able to push this important root through soil that is too hard.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Grow-Poppies-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Mix the poppy seeds with sand. Pour the poppy seeds in a small container such as a pill bottle or pepper shaker. Add some sand, roughly twice as much by volume as the poppy seeds, and stir or shake them together. Poppy seeds are tiny and can clump together when sown. The sand will help space the seeds out, making it easier to plant them evenly.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Grow-Poppies-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Scatter the mixture of seeds and sand barely under the soil. Sprinkle the poppy seeds and sand directly on top of the soil, then cover the seeds with a light dusting of fine soil. Don't bury the seeds, as too much soil will block available sunlight and prevent the tiny poppy seeds from germinating.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 8 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/Grow-Poppies-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Avoid planting the seeds in clumps, which will interfere with growth. If you are planting poppies across a large area, take handfuls of seed and sand mixture and throw them out away from you as you walk across the garden or field.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Water the newly-planted poppy seeds. Use a watering can or spray bottle rather than a strong hose, in order to prevent washing away the tiny poppy seeds. Keep the soil lightly moist once mild spring weather begins. Depending on the poppy variety, it should then take 10 to 30 days for the seeds to sprout.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-9-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 9 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Grow-Poppies-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-9-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Grow-Poppies&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Caring for Poppy Plants\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Caring-for-Poppy-Plants\">Caring for Poppy Plants</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Water as necessary. Poppy plants may rot and die in soaked soils, so only water when the soil feels dry to a finger's depth. Typically, you only need to water the plants once every several days. Increase the amount of water per watering session in hot weather or if the poppies turn brown.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Grow-Poppies-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Avoid watering plants during the early afternoon, especially in sunny weather. The heated water can burn the leaves, and it may evaporate before it can be absorbed.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Reduce the chance of weeds. While it's a good idea to remove weeds competing with your poppies as you see them, young poppy plants are small and easily pulled up by accident or mistaken for undesirable plants. Reduce the ability of weeds to grow in the first place by spreading two to three inches (6 to 8 cm) of organic mulch around the plants. A mulch such as bark chips will look attractive, and will keep the soil moist.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Grow-Poppies-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Cut out excess poppy plants once they've started to grow. Once the plants are one or two inches tall (2.5–5 cm), cut the smaller or weaker plants at the base using garden shears. Keep each remaining plant at least 6 inches (15cm) apart for the best chance at healthy growth and flowering.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/28/Grow-Poppies-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Do not pull the plants out as this may disturb the root systems of the neighboring poppies.</li> \n    <li>Spacing plants out in this manner may also reduce the chance of mold and pest attacks, due to good air circulation and lower frequency of transmitting these problems from one plant to another.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Fertilize only if necessary. If you wish to hasten the growing rate, or if your soil is poor, you may add fertilizer once the plants are at least 5 inches (13cm) tall, and preferably 10 inches (26cm) for taller species. Use a low nitrogen, neutral pH fertilizer and apply as instructed on the packaging.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Grow-Poppies-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Fertilizers display the balance of nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium using three numbers. A low nitrogen fertilizer will have a lower first number, for example 2-5-5.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove dead blooms for additional flowers, or leave them on to cause the plants to seed. Removing the spent blooms where they meet the stalk will encourage the plant to keep blooming throughout the summer. If left alone, the plants will turn yellow and wilt, but after several weeks they will drop their seeds naturally and likely result in dozens of new plants next year.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/85/Grow-Poppies-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Note that you should <i>not</i> cut off withered leaves from perennials if you would like them to remain healthy and bloom again next year.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup> Allow the leaves to die naturally, and hide the brown color with longer-blooming flower varieties if you wish to keep your garden colorful.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Acquire seeds from your best plants. If you would like a new crop of poppy seeds, cut off the bulbous seed pods once they stand vertical and feel chalky to the touch. Dry them in the sunlight, cut them open, and shake them through a sieve over a container to catch the poppy seeds in.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup> Because each plant produces hundreds of seeds, limit your collection to the healthiest and most attractive plants.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 15 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Grow-Poppies-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Grow-Poppies&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Transplanting Poppy Plants\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Transplanting-Poppy-Plants\">Transplanting Poppy Plants</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Avoid transplanting adult plants where possible. Transplanting plants allow you to place the poppies more accurately, rather than casting them across the garden and seeing which seeds mature. However, due to their single, fragile taproot, poppies are easily killed during transplanting, especially large, adult plants. If possible, transplant poppy plants when they are young seedlings less than 3 inches (7.5cm) tall, and leave adult plants in their current container.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-16-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 16 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e2/Grow-Poppies-Step-16-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-16-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you must transplant adult, perennial poppy plants, try to do so in late summer, after the most active growth period but before they begin to seed.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Check the soil in your new location. Poppies require loose, well draining soil, and exposure to at least 6 hours of sunlight a day. Improve the soil by mixing in compost or manure if necessary.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 17 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Grow-Poppies-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>More detail can be found in the section on planting seeds.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Transplant in the evening if possible. Poppies are infamously fragile after transplanting, and they are more likely to die if they are exposed to more sunlight. Transplant in the early evening whenever possible to give them a full night of darkness to adjust to their new situation.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 18 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Grow-Poppies-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Water the seedlings an hour before transplanting. It may take time for the poppies to adjust to the new location before the root begins to take in more water. Make sure they have at least some water stored already by watering them an hour or more before the transplant.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Grow-Poppies#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-19-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 19 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Grow-Poppies-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-19-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Dig a hole in the new location larger than the root ball. If you were growing your seedling in a small container, make the hole larger than the container. Otherwise, you may need to guess at the size required, or pull out an extra seedling you do not intend to grow to examine its size.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-20-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 20 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Grow-Poppies-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-20-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Remove a clump of soil around the poppy plant carefully. If you are transplanting from a container of several seedlings, carefully gather the soil around a central seedling, detaching other seedlings in the soil or moving them to the edge of the pot. This central seedling should not be handled directly, in order to minimize the damage.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-21-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 21 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Grow-Poppies-Step-21-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-21-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Plant the poppy plant to the same depth in the new soil. Try to keep the plant buried at the same depth it was before. Move it as gently as possible to avoid damaging the roots. Pack the soil loosely around the plant. Water it to hold the soil together, then care for it as you would any poppy plant.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Grow-Poppies-Step-22-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Grow Poppies Step 22 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Grow-Poppies-Step-22-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-22-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Grow-Poppies&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Grow-Poppies&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you plant poppies in pots, thin the young seedlings down to one per pot once they reach 1 inch (2.5cm) in height. Use a biodegradable pot that can be planted directly in the soil if you plan to move them to your garden later, since poppies handle transplants poorly.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Grow-Poppies&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Slugs can threaten young poppy seedlings. Protect the plants by using disposable, clear plastic cups as mini greenhouses until the plants have out-grown them. Cut a few holes near the top of the upside down cups and weigh them down with a rock.</li> \n  <li>If mold has started growing on a poppy plant, you may attempt to treat with a gardener's fungicide, but the plant has a low chance of survival. Keep plants spaced out and reduce watering to prevent creating an environment where mold can thrive.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Grow-Poppies&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Manure or compost</li> \n  <li>Poppy seeds</li> \n  <li>Pill bottle or small container</li> \n  <li>Sand</li> \n  <li>Stick or hoe</li> \n  <li>Hose and spray nozzle or watering can</li> \n  <li>General purpose liquid or granular fertilizer</li> \n  <li>Organic mulch</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Grow-Poppies&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Plant-Hyacinths\" title=\"Plant Hyacinths\">Plant class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sun, 06 Mar 2022 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Grow-Poppies-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"a8b98f92360df5384caf358541d44f62","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn46@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-54-966_91a0235a19e3f35d.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":68478,"destBytes":35272,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Grow-Poppies-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn46@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-54-966_91a0235a19e3f35d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/32/Grow-Poppies-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn96@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-11-762_dbada89f5d534a52.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d7/Grow-Poppies-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn89@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-11-183_c80de28de53c1314.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Grow-Poppies-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn62@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-11-567_625fb01715f4357f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Grow-Poppies-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn17@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-12-566_7255745d4b501c60.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Grow-Poppies-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Grow-Poppies-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn86@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-11-067_2e28eba0825a73b7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3b/
