g":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn58@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-12-374_ced1d74bfe4258c7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Grow-Poppies-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-18-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn54@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-12-750_75ff59cf75518361.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Grow-Poppies-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-19-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn89@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-09-927_6ae01b1d6d0493eb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Grow-Poppies-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-20-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn12@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-12-178_9fa485d16dde5eec.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Grow-Poppies-Step-21-Version-3.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-21-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn87@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-11-481_f1d7f10c784b204a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a9/Grow-Poppies-Step-22-Version-2.jpg/aid1135536-v4-728px-Grow-Poppies-Step-22-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn25@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-11-351_e89ff85a4265e212.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693970},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Changing your part is a great way to change up your look and accentuate your face. There are six basic face shapes: oval, oblong, square, heart, diamond, and round. Each of these shapes is best suited to a different style of part, and many face shapes look great with a few different kinds of parts. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Determining Your Face Shape\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Determining-Your-Face-Shape\">Determining Your Face Shape</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Look at length versus width. A deciding factor in finding your face shape is whether your face is longer than it is wide or wider than it is long.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use a flexible measuring tape or string to measure. Measure the length from the top of your hairline to your chin, and measure width all the way across your face at the level of the bridge of your nose. Also measure the width of the top of your hairline and the width across your jaw.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup> Write down your measurements on a piece of paper to refer back to.</li> \n    <li>You have an oval face if your face length is 1.5 times the width.</li> \n    <li>You have a round face if your lengths and widths are almost the same.</li> \n    <li>An oblong face shape has much more length than width.</li> \n    <li>You have a square face if the width across your hairline is the same width as your jaw.</li> \n    <li>Heart shaped faces have their greatest width at the cheekbones paired with a forehead and jawline of almost the same width.</li> \n    <li>A diamond face is wider across the forehead and narrow at the chin with prominent cheekbones.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Look at your jaw line. The shape of your jawline can also be a secondary indicator of the shape of your face.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you have a squared jawline, you probably have a square face.</li> \n    <li>If you have a more soft, rounded jawline, you might have an oval, oblong, triangular or round face.</li> \n    <li>If your jaw comes to a point, you might have a heart or diamond face shape.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Take a short cut. You don’t necessarily have to determine all of your measurements to find your face shape. If you want, use a simpler method to determine your face shape by eyeing it.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>After you get out of the shower, stand in front of the steamy bathroom mirror. Drawing the shape of your face in the steam of the mirror, or stand in front of a clear mirror, and draw your face in lipstick or eyeliner.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup> This will help you more clearly see the shape of your face.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Look at other faces. Looking at celebrities can help you confirm your own face shape. Has anyone ever told you that you look like a celebrity? See what face shape that person has because yours might be similar.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Celebrities with round faces: Reese Witherspoon, Cara Delevingne, Kate Upton, Kate Bosworth<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Celebrities with diamond faces: Tyra Banks, Viola Davis, Rihanna, Shilpa Shetty</li> \n    <li>Celebrities with heart faces: Julianne Moore, Lea Michele, Lucy Hale</li> \n    <li>Celebrities with square faces: Olivia Wilde, Katie Holmes, Jennifer Garner, Rachel McAdams<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Celebrities with oblong faces: Liv Tyler, Megan Fox, Gisele<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Celebrities with oval faces: Beyoncé, Charlize Theron, Jennifer Aniston, Olivia Munn<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Determine your symmetry. Do you have a “good side” when you take photographs? This might be due to facial asymmetry.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To find out how symmetrical your face is, take a blank white sheet of paper and cover one half of your face and then the other. Line the edge up with the middle of your nose. Does one half appear smaller?</li> \n    <li>If so, as you are parting your hair, part it above the larger side of your face to create the illusion of symmetry.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Knowing Which Part to Use for Your Face Shape\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Knowing-Which-Part-to-Use-for-Your-Face-Shape\">Knowing Which Part to Use for Your Face Shape</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Part your hair in the middle for oblong, oval, round, or heart shaped faces.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To achieve the perfect middle part, hold a comb up in line with your nose. Keeping that line, mark the part on top of your head, and brush your hair to either side.</li> \n    <li>Make sure the line is perfectly straight, as middle parts are very noticeable. You also want to keep your hair constantly clean.</li> \n    <li>For a round face, a middle part gives the appearance of a longer face and makes features look symmetrical. This can be especially slimming if the hair is shorter around your face.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>In oblong faces, a middle part adds the look of roundness.</li> \n    <li>If you have an oval face you’re lucky because oval faces look great with any type of part.</li> \n    <li>If your face is asymmetrical, try a middle part that is just slightly off center. This will help you avoid accentuating the asymmetry of your face.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Part your hair in a slight side part for square, diamond, or oval faces.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You probably have a natural side part. Comb through your hair with your fingers, and see where it naturally falls. This should line up about with the outside of your eyebrow. Then, use a comb to make this part more defined and neat.</li> \n    <li>Side-swept parts give square faces more softness. The part should be slight, as a deep side part will make the angles of the face stand out harshly.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Part your hair in a deep side part for round, heart, diamond, or oval faces.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keeping your part on its natural side, comb your hair over farther than you naturally would. It might take time to train your hair to stay in a deeper part.</li> \n    <li>If you have longer hair, try parting your hair deeply, and then pulling it back into a ponytail so the part stays in place.</li> \n    <li>For heart shaped faces, the deep side part breaks up the sharp line of the chin and softens your cheekbones.</li> \n    <li>A deep part on diamond faces accentuates bone structure and good features.</li> \n    <li>Try a sweeping side part if you want to minimize a prominent forehead.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Part your hair in a zig-zag for any face shape. This part is more about style than complementing a certain face. It works well to give you a tousled-but-put-together vibe and add volume to your roots.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To get a zig-zag part, just find your normal part, and use a comb to alternate pulling sections of your hair from each side of your head over the part in opposite directions. You can create just a few sections or lots of smaller zig-zags.</li> \n    <li>The zig-zag part is usually a centered part, but you can also create a zig-zag side part, if that suits your face shape better.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Perfecting Your Part\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Perfecting-Your-Part\">Perfecting Your Part</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Use product for volume. When you are parting your hair, you can benefit from using product to get some lift at the roots, and make your hair look great.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’ve just washed your hair, use a texturizing spray on damp hair before you blow dry.</li> \n    <li>If you haven’t washed your hair, work some dry shampoo into your roots.</li> \n    <li>If you’re trying to achieve a middle part, consider adding a shine serum or spray into your hair care routine.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Train your new part. If you’re changing your part from one that you’ve had for years, it make take a little bit of coaxing to get your hair to cooperate.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To do this, wash your hair, and blow it dry.</li> \n    <li>As you are blow drying, use a round brush to lift the top of your hair near your crown up and back as you dry. Keep lifting, and don’t let it fall back into your former part. Once it’s dry, you can use a comb to create your new look.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Work with dry hair. When you are working on the look of your part, it’s best to start with dry hair. If you part your hair while it’s wet, you risk it looking limp and flat.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your part does start to look flat, use your fine-toothed comb to tease the hair around it slightly.</li> \n    <li>Side parts especially look great if they’re somewhat imperfect.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Finished.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Part Your Hair for Your Face Shape Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-13.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you like the shape of your face, feel free to play up your favorite features—don't feel like you have to minimize them to look more like someone else's standard of beauty!<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Avoid-Tangled-Hair\" title=\"Avoid Tangled Hair\">Avoid Tangled Hair</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Condition-Your-Hair\" title=\"Condition Your Hair\">Condition Your Hair</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 14 Mar 2022 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"2941d1704b10dc5e6040e9d44605855c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn19@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-14-54-898_5cf67256da2d114f.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":53083,"destBytes":26058,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn19@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-14-54-898_5cf67256da2d114f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn83@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-11-609_b2823d018ea00805.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b1/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn26@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-15-345_9d99aafbfe271d01.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a2/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn6@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-13-943_53a371c4a8d89c68.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn30@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-10-960_ed7a9c827c34eb74.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn11@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-12-564_477756fbf38be958.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6e/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-7-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn48@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-13-183_7ee202ba545e5572.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-8-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn49@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-09-391_afd46068c3cf4345.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn80@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-12-643_e1a361eef0410d7f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e8/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn13@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-11-402_7d11445a329c35c8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn84@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-12-536_b596fc5c77df87f0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/de/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn34@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-09-538_526d6d65d0156c24.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-13.jpg/aid2536131-v4-728px-Part-Your-Hair-for-Your-Face-Shape-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn10@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-09-221_3dea69fd2f276fb2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693962},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Season a Stainless Steel Pan","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>It’s always much easier to cook with pans that don’t stick; however, the majority of nonstick pans on the market contain harmful chemicals that make them less than ideal for cooking. The best, easiest, and healthiest solution to nonstick cookware is seasoning your pans at home! Add oil to a clean stainless steel pan and let it heat to kick off the seasoning process. Afterward, you’ll be able to <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-on-Stainless-Steel\" title=\"Cook on Stainless Steel\">use your freshly seasoned pan</a> to whip up all kinds of tasty meals for you and your family! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Seasoning the Pan\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Seasoning-the-Pan\">Seasoning the Pan</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Wash your pan with soap and warm water. Scrub the pan with a dishrag or sponge. Clean both the inside and outside of the pan as thoroughly as you can. Rinse the pan off with warm water, then let it air dry. Oil will adhere better to a clean pan.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-1-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season a Stainless Steel Pan Step 1 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ec/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid1667178-v4-728px-Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-1-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Choose an oil with a high smoking point to season your pan with. Sesame, vegetable, peanut, and soybean oil are all great choices for seasoning your pan. An oil with a high smoking point will react more readily to the heat as you begin the seasoning process, and will “stick” better to the pan. This helps your seasoning to last longer and be more effective.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-2-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season a Stainless Steel Pan Step 2 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e3/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-2-Version-4.jpg/aid1667178-v4-728px-Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-2-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Pour just enough oil into the pan to thinly coat the bottom. For most pans, this will measure out to about of oil. Swirl the pan around to spread the oil to the sides. Aim to cover the inside of the pan as thoroughly and evenly as possible so the entire interior is seasoned for cooking.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Heat your pan on the stove for 2 minutes over medium heat. Avoid cranking the burner up to high to start off the seasoning process; this will cause the pan to heat unevenly and may burn the oil. Medium heat is not only gentler on the pan and the oil, but will ensure they heat up at an even rate.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-4-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season a Stainless Steel Pan Step 4 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a6/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-4-Version-4.jpg/aid1667178-v4-728px-Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-4-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Alternatively, try seasoning your pan in the oven. Place your pan in the oven and set the temperature to . Let the pan heat in the oven for 1 hour.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove the pan from the heat once the oil starts to smoke. The oil is ready once thin wisps of smoke begin curling up from the pan. It may take around 3 to 5 minutes for this to develop. Immediately take the pan off of the burner and move it to another burner.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Let the oil cool for at least 30 minutes. The oil should at least be lukewarm, if not room temperature. You want the oil to be cool enough to not scald to the touch. This will ensure the oil is safe enough to handle for the rest of the seasoning process.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-6-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season a Stainless Steel Pan Step 6 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a1/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-6-Version-4.jpg/aid1667178-v4-728px-Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-6-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don’t touch the oil to test whether it’s cooled down enough.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Pour all of the excess oil from the pan down your kitchen drain. You will still be able to see some oil in the pan once you’ve finished; this is okay. You can also soak the oil up and dispose with food waste if you don’t want to pour it down the drain. You may still be able to see some oil in the pan once you’ve finished; this is okay.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Wipe the inside of the pan with a paper towel. Wad up the paper towel and run it along the pan in circular motions. This will both sop up any remaining excess oil, as well as give the pan a noticeable shine. The shininess indicates the pan has been sufficiently glossed and is now nonstick!<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Preventing Stick During Cooking\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Preventing-Stick-During-Cooking\">Preventing Stick During Cooking</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Preheat your pan to medium heat before cooking. Doing this will ensure your pan and food heat evenly, and prevent the likelihood of burnt cooking. It should take around 10 minutes for your pan to reach medium temperature.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-9-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season a Stainless Steel Pan Step 9 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/ba/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-9-Version-4.jpg/aid1667178-v4-728px-Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-9-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Monitor the stove temperature as you cook. Avoid setting the burner to high when you use any pan—especially a seasoned pan. The higher the cooking temperature, the more likely your food will stick to the pan as it cooks.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-10-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season a Stainless Steel Pan Step 10 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6f/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-10-Version-4.jpg/aid1667178-v4-728px-Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-10-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Thaw foods to room temperature before you cook. Cold food will ultimately stick to hot pans, causing burning and creating a mess. Let your food thaw in the refrigerator, but take it out for 1 to 2 hours before cooking so it can rise to room temperature.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-11-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season a Stainless Steel Pan Step 11 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-11-Version-4.jpg/aid1667178-v4-728px-Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-11-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don’t let raw food sit out for any longer than 2 hours, or you increase the risk of bacteria and food poisoning!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Don’t crowd the pan with ingredients. Filling your pan up with more ingredients than it can hold leads to unbalanced temperatures and sticking. If you want to cook multiple ingredients in the same pan, stick to only 2 or 3 at a time, and space them out so they each have their own section in the pan.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Only cook acidic foods, water-based foods, and sauces in your stainless steel pan. Fruits, veggies, tomato sauce, gravies, and broths are all great foods to cook in a seasoned stainless steel pan. Alternatively, you can use your pan to cook your morning eggs, or sear a cut of salmon for dinner. Stainless steel pans are best designed for cooking these types of foods.<br /><br /></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Storing and Cleaning a Seasoned Pan\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Storing-and-Cleaning-a-Seasoned-Pan\">Storing and Cleaning a Seasoned Pan</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Place a few paper towels inside your seasoned pan before stacking it. Stacking pans is a common and useful storage method, but it can easily scratch up the insides of your pans. A scratched pan can’t be seasoned as effectively. Stuffing a few paper towels inside will give your seasoned pan the protection it needs.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Wipe your pan out with a paper towel once you finish cooking. Washing a seasoned pan with soap and water after every cooking session will strip away the oil, forcing you to reseason. The oil left in the pan is meant to protect it from stuck-on food, making soap and water unnecessary until your pan becomes too messy to use.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-15-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season a Stainless Steel Pan Step 15 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-15-Version-3.jpg/aid1667178-v4-728px-Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-15-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Clean out a messy pan with soap and water. Eventually, your seasoned pan will become messy with residue. In this case, it’s fine to clean it out. Use warm water and a nonabrasive cleaning tool, like a soft sponge or cloth dishrag.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-16-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season a Stainless Steel Pan Step 16 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8e/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-16-Version-3.jpg/aid1667178-v4-728px-Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-16-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don’t wash your pan until it is totally cool to the touch.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Wipe your pan dry with a paper towel as soon as you finish washing it. This will keep it from spotting.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove stubborn, stuck-on food by boiling water for 5 minutes. If there's any residue left over, add dish soap to the pan before submerging the residue with water. Place the pan on the stove and turn the burner on high. Let the pan boil for 5 minutes, then pour out the hot water. The rest of the residue should scrub right off!<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Reseason your pan with fresh oil after you wash it. Once you wash your pan with soap and water, it's no longer seasoned. To make sure it continues to be a perfect, non-stick pan, repeat the seasoning process!\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-18-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Season a Stainless Steel Pan Step 18 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/62/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-18-Version-3.jpg/aid1667178-v4-728px-Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan-Step-18-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Scrub a sticky pan with salt and oil to get rid of constant sticking.</li> \n  <li>Don’t use any cooking sprays on a seasoned pan. This will only leave behind extra oil to gunk up the pan, and make your food more likely to stick.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li id=\"_note-1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-a-Stainless-Steel-Pan#_ref-1\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\"
