href=\"http://www.webmd.com/fitness-exercise/features/hydration-key-to-exercise-success\">http://www.webmd.com/fitness-exercise/features/hydration-key-to-exercise-success</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Play-Rugby#_ref-14\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://laws.worldrugby.org/?law=13&amp;language=EN\">http://laws.worldrugby.org/?law=13&amp;language=EN</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 09 Mar 2022 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Play-Rugby-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"7126617d0e912625d17996b70ed82c17","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn29@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-14-54-969_b020789496be6c46.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":64234,"destBytes":41634,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8d/Play-Rugby-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn29@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-14-54-969_b020789496be6c46.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Play-Rugby-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn56@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-11-757_fa4e0e5ad8e61c48.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Play-Rugby-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn38@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-12-661_b925ed2dc84df976.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Play-Rugby-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn70@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-10-265_ebafd8f77296a687.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8f/Play-Rugby-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn37@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-09-215_7f2d539c87d059d0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Play-Rugby-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn61@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-09-991_2678692f6f7a28c0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Play-Rugby-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Play-Rugby-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn16@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-13-739_11ed8158b1467f37.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Play-Rugby-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-9-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn48@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-22-756_85c9fa555fd6cc3d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Play-Rugby-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-10-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn17@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-10-952_7400d8d005983b62.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/37/Play-Rugby-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-11-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn58@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-12-751_51dce7aacf5fd984.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e0/Play-Rugby-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-12-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn51@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-13-971_5efd756547c15d1b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c0/Play-Rugby-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn82@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-14-011_9dbbbd4d296e31fb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Play-Rugby-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-14-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn9@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-13-943_04664f09c9fa9ecd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Play-Rugby-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-15-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn77@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-10-246_506ed7c9ecffcdf9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Play-Rugby-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-16-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn3@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-09-195_092740c324fb68c6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Play-Rugby-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-17-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn46@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-11-363_49474de05ff32cdb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Play-Rugby-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-18-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn54@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-11-537_d269f151e1e4117b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/91/Play-Rugby-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-19-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn49@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-12-937_e405a7e3e1f78eec.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Play-Rugby-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-20-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn100@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-12-995_9a272b1342374393.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/73/Play-Rugby-Step-21-Version-2.jpg/aid47711-v4-728px-Play-Rugby-Step-21-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn25@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-09-736_a81de42ab71e87ff.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693956},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Toss Pizza Dough","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>If you plan to toss, start with the recipe. Without the right kind of flour and the right approach, your dough will not develop the gluten it needs for a strong, stretchy texture. Once you have the right recipe, practice shaping and tossing until you become a true <i>pizzaiolo</i>. Not all pizza chefs toss their dough, but it is an excellent way to flatten and widen your dough with minimal compression, keeping the dough light.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Toss-Pizza-Dough&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ingredients\">Ingredients</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>1 cup (240mL) warm water</li> \n  <li>1 cup (240mL) ice cold water</li> \n  <li>1/2 tablespoon (7.5mL) salt</li> \n  <li>1 tablespoon (15mL) sugar</li> \n  <li>2 tablespoon (30mL) <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Choose-Olive-Oil\" title=\"Choose Olive Oil\">olive oil</a></li> \n  <li>1 packet active dry yeast</li> \n  <li>About 5½ cups (685g) flour</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Toss-Pizza-Dough&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Toss-Pizza-Dough&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Making the Dough\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-the-Dough\">Making the Dough</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Choose your recipe. Most pizza chefs experiment with dozens of recipes before they find their personal, perfect pizza. If you don't have a personal favorite yet, the recipe described here makes a strong, Neapolitan-style pizza that should resist tears while tossing.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Your quest will be easier if you familiarize yourself with baking percentages, and keep detailed notes on each recipe.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Choose your flour. The flour's protein content is incredibly important for pizza, especially when you plan to toss it. Look for bread flour or pizza flour with a protein content of at least 12.5%.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Mix the yeast into warm water. The water should be \"blood temperature,\" or close to 96ºF (35.5ºC). Let this mixture stand until the yeast is dissolved and begins to bubble.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Mix wet ingredients together. Mix cold water, sugar, salt, and olive oil in a separate bowl.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Combine all ingredients. Place the flour in a large bowl. Stir the activated yeast, then pour it into the flour. Pour the cold water mixture as well.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Knead-Dough\" title=\"Knead Dough\">Knead the dough.</a> You may knead by hand or with a dough hook attached to a low-speed electric mixer. Knead until the dough is glossy and tacky, but not sticky. You should be able to pinch a small piece and pull it thin enough to let light pass through. This is a sign of a strong, high-gluten dough that will stay together when tossed, and make a chewy, tender crust.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6b/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Results can vary with humidity and other unpredictable factors. Add a little flour if the mixture is sticky, or a little water if the dough is dry.</li> \n    <li>This usually takes 5–15 minutes by hand, or 2–4 minutes in an electric mixer.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Let rise overnight. Brush the dough with olive oil and store, covered, in the refrigerator. Leave overnight (or for at least 5 hours) to allow gluten to develop further. The cold temperature of the fridge slows yeast activity, preventing excessive rising from the long waiting period.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup> Cold dough is also easier to handle.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Place the dough in an airtight container with enough room for the dough to double in size.</li> \n    <li>Alternatively, leave covered with a warm towel for 40–60 minutes at room temperature, or until dough doubles in size. Chill for one hour in the refrigerator.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Toss-Pizza-Dough&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Shaping the Dough\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Shaping-the-Dough\">Shaping the Dough</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Cut the dough ball in half. Scoop up the dough ball with a dough scraper, if you have one, to avoid stretching it. Cut it in half to form the dough for two smaller pizzas. These will be more convenient to handle and fit in a home oven. For the instructions below, use one dough ball at a time.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 8 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Make sure that your pizza dough is room temperature before you start working with it.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Coat generously with flour. Coat both sides with plenty of flour. Drop the dough ball on a flat, floured surface, flipped over so the side that was underneath while rising is now on top.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-9-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 9 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/47/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-9-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To reduce mess, use cornmeal or semolina instead of regular flour.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>If your dough or hands stick at any point during the rest of the process, add more flour.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Flatten the dough. Slap the ball of dough flat with your hand, kept as flat as possible. Don't press too hard, or you'll squeeze out the air and create a hard, dense crust. Just press until it is relatively flat, but still squishy.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 10 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Define the outer crust. Hold your fingers straight and together. Press into the dough about from the edge. Repeat this motion around the whole circle, forming a groove and a raised outer crust.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 11 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Push the dough outward. Keep your fingers straight and together. Hold your hands flat, just above the dough, with your fingers pressing into the groove you just made. Fan your fingers outward a little, pressing against the crust. Bring your fingers together and rotate the dough a little, then repeat this fanning motion around the whole edge.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup> This will make the outer crust edge thinner, and the pizza a bit larger.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-12-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 12 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-12-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don't press your palms against the base of the dough. This can lead to uneven crust or tears.</li> \n    <li>Beginners can use a rolling pin when starting out. This is easier, but usually results in a denser crust.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stretch the dough. Once again, hold your fingers straight and together. Place them lightly on the dough in a comfortable position in front of you, angled toward each other. Press your fingertips against the edge, and push one hand outward to gently stretch that small area of the pizza. Rotate the dough and repeat, moving around the dough several times. With practice, you can use a fluid, fast motion, moving your hands in small circles.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup> Stop when the dough is getting thin, and approaching the size you want.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-13-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 13 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a3/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-13-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Never move your hands in completely opposite directions, as this will create a thin center. Move at an angle instead to stretch just the outer area, leaving a small hump in the center of the dough.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>You can instead press the side of your hand down into the groove, then push directly outward to stretch the edge. Use your other hand to rotate the dough as you go.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Toss-Pizza-Dough&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tossing the Dough\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tossing-the-Dough\">Tossing the Dough</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Slap the dough between your hands (optional). Slapping is an easier way to hand shape your pizza. Some chefs slap, some toss, and some start with slapping and finish with a toss or two. None of these methods are more correct than another. If you decide to slap, here's how it goes:<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 14 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Drape the dough over your palm and forearm. The more of your arm you use, the less likely the dough is to break.</li> \n    <li>\"Slap\" the dough onto your opposite palm, letting it drape over your other hand and forearm. If your dough is in danger of tearing, let it drape gently instead of using force.</li> \n    <li>Repeat this motion back and forth. Each time you \"slap,\" the dough should rotate about one quarter turn. This rotation is vital for making the dough wide and even.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Drape the dough on a fist and palm. If your dough looks strong and hasn't yet reached the desired size, it's time to adopt the tossing position. Extend your dominant hand as a flat palm, with fingers together. Keep your other hand in a fist to \"anchor\" the dough. Drape the pizza dough over both hands, supporting opposite sides of the dough.<sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup><sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 15 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/84/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Rotate your arms toward your body. Rotate your arms inward to get ready for the throw. (If you are using your right palm, rotate your arms to the left.) This allows more rotation during the throw, imparting the spin that shapes the dough in the air.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 16 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6b/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-16-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Bring your hands up and around. Bring your palm up and around, until the back of your hand is in front of your face.<sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup> Follow with your fist to continue supporting the pizza, but focus on your palm, which will do the tossing. Practice this motion without tossing the pizza first, then try again with moderate speed during your toss.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 17 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Start with a more gentle throw than you think you need. Too little force, and the pizza doesn't leave your hand. Too much force, and the pizza flies across the room.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Release the pizza. Bring the upward motion of your palm to an abrupt stop when it comes in front of your face. This will send the pizza flying upward a short distance. In the air, it should spin at the same speed your hands rotated. The force from spinning pushes the dough flatter and wider, without pressing out the air.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 18 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Follow through. Although your hand stops moving upward, it should still complete the arch of its movement after the pizza is released. Follow through by moving your palm around and out, as though swatting a fly in front of your face. A smooth follow-through ensures that your hand is rotating at the moment when you release the pizza.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-19-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 19 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-19-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Don't worry too much about this for your first few tosses. It's more important to catch the falling pizza than to get the right hand shape.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Catch the dough. Catch the dough with both fists and forearms. Use as much of your forearm as you can, to avoid puncturing it. If you have a strong dough, you may be able to catch it on one fist, but this is risky for most recipes.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-20-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 20 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-20-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you tossed with your right palm, catch the dough mostly on your left arm.</li> \n    <li>Expert dough tossers \"catch\" the dough on their fingertips, sending it spinning again without letting it rest. This is a complex technique that involves sending the dough in multiple trajectories and angles.<sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup> It's best not to try this until you're a more experience <i>pizzaiolo</i>.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Repeat as necessary. If you slapped the dough or hand-stretched it heavily, you may only need one toss to get your pizza to the size you need. If you only used light hand-stretching, you may toss it several times. Once the pizza reaches the desired size, place the dough on a pizza screen, pizza stone, or baking sheet. You're ready to add the toppings.<sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-21-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Toss Pizza Dough Step 21 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-21-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-21-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The dough is ready when you say it's ready. The size of your oven and personal preference for crust thickness are the only criteria you need when cooking at home.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Toss-Pizza-Dough&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Toss-Pizza-Dough&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you get very good at tossing, you can enter competitions! To accomplish the fancy tricks, most dough tossing champions use a special dough not intended for eating. The key to an extra-stretchy, durable dough is high gluten flour, large amounts of salt, and very cold water (except when activating yeast).</li> \n  <li>Longer rise times can be used if the amount of yeast is reduced.</li> \n  <li>Try not to use too much flour when you knead the dough, or it will be too dry and not stretch easily. You can be more generous when shaping and tossing.</li> \n  <li>If you dough is hard to stretch, leave it to rest on the bench-top covered with a damp cloth for at least an hour and then try again. Dough will not stretch easily straight out of the fridge either.</li> \n  <li>If your dough tears at any point, fold the tear shut, or press it closed with more dough torn off the edge. A pizza that tears probably can't take much more stretching. You may need to settle for a thicker crust than you planned.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Toss-Pizza-Dough&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>It is essential to knead the dough long enough, but not too long. If using a powerful electric mixer, it is possible to over-knead. The symptom of this is stringy dough that breaks apart into threads.</li> \n  <li>Throwing the dough too high can be disastrous. It will either land too hard and tear, or get stuck to your ceiling. A short hop is all you need.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Toss-Pizza-Dough&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Pizza\" title=\"Make Pizza\">Make Pizza</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Pizza-Dough\" title=\"Make Pizza Dough\">Make Pizza Dough</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Dessert-Pizza\" title=\"Make Dessert Pizza\">Make Dessert Pizza</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Thin-Crust-Pizza\" title=\"Make Thin Crust Pizza\">Make Thin Crust Pizza</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Toss-Pizza-Dough&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Recipe adapted from <a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://www.myrecipes.com/recipe/tonys-pizza-dough\">http://www.myrecipes.com/recipe/tonys-pizza-dough</a>.</li>\n </ul> \n <p><br /> href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Toss-Pizza-Dough#_ref-20\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\">[v161921_b01]. 18 October 2021.</span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 12 Mar 2022 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"b88a0c1ba0288c5b30143ade91f8e23d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn34@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-14-54-971_14da1d3d1beeab6d.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":60437,"destBytes":35268,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn34@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-14-54-971_14da1d3d1beeab6d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn33@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-12-305_bf3edf18f23805ee.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn17@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-14-188_dfe8543dd2fc8488.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/27/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn45@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-12-204_932938169fc4810f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn72@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-13-311_a67f07a2d795ba2b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6b/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn76@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-12-850_6707c49a3850f590.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn6@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-10-187_3eab72dcc728452d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e9/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn74@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-09-237_786afd44ad0c1507.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/47/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-9-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-10-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8c/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-11-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn78@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-11-165_ff5294802e0c72e9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-12-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn30@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-12-834_69dc293ec16be76b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a3/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-13-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-14-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn87@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-13-441_c12e2e22f52ea0f1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/84/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-15-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn88@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-12-588_c05c1c49f122e08c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6b/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-16-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-16-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn18@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-11-173_84165f90fd470699.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3d/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-17-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn33@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-10-223_b8d5b07595ce8569.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-18-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn27@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-09-511_19ada83155d264ed.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9c/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-19-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn84@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-09-135_1cd2ca41f28bd0e7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/74/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-20-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn64@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-13-379_e788f64f85e5a657.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/46/Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-21-Version-2.jpg/aid20462-v4-728px-Toss-Pizza-Dough-Step-21-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn22@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-10-936_a84d1e905b96226b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693948},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Make a Rubber Band Ball","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>There are many great reasons to have a rubber band ball. You can bounce it, use it to keep all your rubber bands in once place, or squeeze it to strengthen your hand muscles. If you enjoy making your first one, this might even become a hobby. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Making a Rubber Band Ball\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Making-a-Rubber-Band-Ball\">Making a Rubber Band Ball</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Create a core. You can start with any small object, such as a marble or golf ball. A \"true\" rubber band ball, however, includes no other materials. Here's how to get it started:<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Rubber Band Ball Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid14836-v4-728px-Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Select a short, thick rubber band, such as a band used to secure vegetables.</li> \n    <li>Fold this rubber band in half, then in half again, then a third time if possible. Do not twist it; you should end up with a flat \"stack\" of rubber.</li> \n    <li>While pinching the thick band flat, wrap a thinner rubber band around it.</li> \n    <li>Twist the slack of the thinner band and wrap it over the thick one in the other direction.</li> \n    <li>Continue to twist and wrap until there is no more slack in the thin band.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wrap rubber bands around the core. Start with two rubber bands placed in a criss-cross shape over the core. Make sure they're tightly secured. You may have to twist and wrap them around the core a few times. \n   <ul>\n    <li>Start with the smallest bands first, since they won't be useful once your ball passes a certain size.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add more rubber bands until the ball is smooth. Keep wrapping rubber bands so that you form a ball. Space the rubber bands evenly so that no one side of the ball is larger than any other. A ball without an object in the core will start out lumpy, but it should become smooth by the time it reaches the size of a golf ball.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li> \n  <li>Test the ball. Toss it in the air, or bounce it against the wall. Your new rubber band ball should have plenty of spring. Enjoy it as is, or keep adding more rubber bands and watch it grow. \n   <ul>\n    <li>Get it to the size of a tennis ball for the best bounce.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Rubber Band Ball Challenges\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Rubber-Band-Ball-Challenges\">Rubber Band Ball Challenges</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Find all your rubber bands for free. Since rubber band balls are all about the challenge anyway, why not make it a little harder? Try expanding your ball without paying for any rubber bands. Here are a few places to look for them:\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Rubber Band Ball Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid14836-v4-728px-Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Ask friends and neighbors for spares.</li> \n    <li>Ask postal workers, newspaper delivery people, and other door-to-door delivery workers.</li> \n    <li>Look in shoe stores, which may use rubber bands to hold the shoe boxes closed.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make a ball without twisting any rubber bands. If you don't twist the rubber bands, they lie flat against each other, with no room for air. This makes the densest, bounciest ball. The trick to this is finding each new rubber band <i>exactly</i> the right size, so there's no slack when you loop it around the ball once.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Rubber Band Ball Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid14836-v4-728px-Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Make it massive. Rubber band balls are extremely dense, so after a certain point they'll be too heavy to bounce without breaking something. After that, the challenge is to make it as large as possible. You can even beat the world record, if you can find 700,000 rubber bands.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make a Rubber Band Ball Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-7.jpg/aid14836-v4-728px-Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Once the ball is about the size of a basketball, wear safety goggles. Plenty of rubber bands will snap after this point, and you don't want them hitting your eyes.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Rubber bands decay over time. To stop it shrinking or breaking apart, your project will need regular reinforcement.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cut your old ball in half. Once you have a basketball-sized rubber band ball, it will probably sit there in the corner of your room, getting greyer and more frayed. Want to get one final moment of fun? Saw it in half and watch the insides emerge on their own, like a bizarre colony of worms.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup> If that description didn't turn you off the hobby forever, get out there and start creating!<br /><br />]</li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>If you're having trouble making a rubber band core, start with several short rubber bands instead. Wad them into a ball and pinch them together as you wrap thinner rubber bands around them. Some people find this easier, but the core will end up lumpier and may spring apart before it has a solid layer wrapped around it.</li> \n  <li>When the ball gets too large to fit your rubber bands around, cut two bands in half, tie the ends together, and tie that around the ball.</li> \n  <li>Colorful rubber bands will make the rubber band ball more exciting and different, but the colors will fade with time.</li> \n  <li>For a neat gift idea, why not use a paper with a secret message as the core? Or to pull a mean prank, make the ball obnoxiously large and tell your friend their crush put a note in the center.</li> \n  <li>Make different layers of colors in the ball.</li> \n  <li>You can use different colors of rubber bands, they can be however you want them.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Rubber will melt (vulcanize) naturally over time. Heat and UV light can speed this up, so keep the ball away from warm areas and sunlight.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Things You'll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Rubber bands</li> \n  <li>A piece of foil or a small ball (optional)</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 10 Mar 2022 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid14836-v4-728px-Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"8ee2794887feb776d5856891d7ea6cfe","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn52@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-55-086_3b4d52cc88bac152.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":38256,"destBytes":17332,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid14836-v4-728px-Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn52@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-55-086_3b4d52cc88bac152.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0a/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid14836-v4-728px-Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn87@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-12-059_053509368de54f26.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cc/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid14836-v4-728px-Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn3@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-13-613_d70e3718c3be37b1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2a/Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-7.jpg/aid14836-v4-728px-Make-a-Rubber-Band-Ball-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn22@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-14-104_cbd6c52b7b9b109f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693951},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Make Better Tasting Instant Coffee","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Instant coffee dates back to at least 1890 and has been a major industry for over a century.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> Most consumers, however, like it for the convenience and not the taste. Learn how to leave \"coffee flavored water\" behind, but be prepared for trial and error. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ingredients\">Ingredients</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Water (bottled or filtered might be best, depending on your local water supply)</li> \n  <li>Instant coffee</li> \n  <li>Milk or cream (optional)</li> \n  <li>Sugar (optional)</li> \n  <li>Flavorings, such as cocoa powder, vanilla, or cinnamon (optional)</li> \n  <li>Flavored creamer (optional)</li> \n  <li>Flavored syrup (optional)</li> \n  <li>Vanilla extract (optional)</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Improving Your Technique\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Improving-Your-Technique\">Improving Your Technique</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Buy quality instant coffee. Almost no instant coffee brands can compete with ground, but some are pretty decent. Try to find packaging labeled \"freeze-dried,\" which tends to produce a truer coffee flavor than \"spray drying.\"<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup> If the label doesn't specify, check the consistency: granules are more likely to be freeze-dried than powder is, though this is not a guarantee.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup> Finally, more expensive brands tend to taste better.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-1-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Better Tasting Instant Coffee Step 1 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-1-Version-5.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-1-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you're not sure where to start, try Medaglia d'Oro or Starbucks VIA Colombia. These tend to convert more coffee snobs than most brands.</li> \n    <li>Instant espresso powder is a different product, meant for baking instead of drinking.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Heat a kettle of water. Don't use water that's been sitting in your kettle, which can pick up off-flavors or become \"flat\" from repeated boiling. If you live in a hard water area or your tap water just tastes bad, put it through a water filter first.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-2-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Better Tasting Instant Coffee Step 2 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-2-Version-5.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-2-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you don't have a kettle, microwave a mug of water before adding the coffee.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup> Microwaved water can \"explode\" if overheated. Prevent this by putting a wooden popsicle stick or teaspoon of sugar in the cup.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Measure the instant coffee into a mug. Follow the package instructions the first time you try a brand. If it's too strong or too watery for your tastes, you can adjust the ratio of coffee and water later. Most importantly, use the same spoon and the same mug each time. If you switch to a different size each time, you can't pinpoint a ratio you enjoy.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If there's no recommendation on the package, try 1 slightly rounded teaspoon (5mL) per 8 oz (240mL).</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stir in a little cold water (optional). Add just enough cold water to wet all the coffee, stirring it into a paste.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup> This preparation gives your coffee a smoother flavor, although it won't always have a major effect.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Pour in the hot water. Instant coffee has already been extracted in water before drying, so the flavor is already set. This means the temperature of the water is much less important than for normal coffee. Instant coffee drinkers disagree over whether boiling water can affect the taste. If you're concerned, just let the kettle cool down for a couple of minutes first.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Stir in the sugar and milk (optional). Even if you prefer black coffee, most instant blends could use the flavor help. Stir in as much or as little as you like, making sure all the sugar dissolves. If your instant coffee has a particularly bad taste, the cream will hide it better than milk.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Taste and adjust. The most effective way to improve your cup is to keep experimenting and to keep track of what you tried. Try an extra teaspoon (5mL) of coffee next time if the brew was too watery, or add another pinch of sugar if it tastes too bitter. Instant coffee will never be gourmet, but your choices can make it enjoyable.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Better Tasting Instant Coffee Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Use the same spoon and same mug each time so you have a benchmark for the coffee to water ratio.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Store the leftovers in an airtight container. Humidity will spoil the flavor of your instant coffee. Keep it out by sealing the container tightly.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Better Tasting Instant Coffee Step 8 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you live in a humid climate, transfer the leftovers to smaller containers as you use them up. This will minimize the amount of air that contacts the coffee. In extra-humid tropics, the refrigerator might be drier than your cupboards.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Customizing Instant Coffee\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Customizing-Instant-Coffee\">Customizing Instant Coffee</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Replace the water with milk. Some say that the coffee itself is a lost cause. If the techniques above don't help, try replacing all the water with hot milk. Heat the milk over the stovetop until it begins to bubble around the edges. Pour it onto the coffee powder instead of water.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep an eye on the milk and stir occasionally. Unattended milk can overflow rapidly.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Froth milk into a cappuccino. Your \"instant cappuccino\" won't impress an Italian, but a little froth can go a long way. If you don't have a handheld frother, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Froth-Milk-for-Cappuccino-Without-Fancy-Tools\" title=\"Froth Milk for Cappuccino Without Fancy Tools\">froth the milk and instant coffee</a> by whisking or shaking it in a jar.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Better Tasting Instant Coffee Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To froth up the mixture with a spoon, add the instant coffee and sugar to a cup, then stir in enough water to make a paste. Beat this with a spoon until foamy, then stir in the hot milk.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add flavors. Strong, usually sweet flavors are another way to hide poor tastes. Here are a few suggestions:<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Replace the milk and sugar with flavored creamers, or homemade <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Flavored-Milk\" title=\"Make Flavored Milk\">flavored milk</a>.</li> \n    <li>Add flavorings such as vanilla extract, cocoa powder, or ground cinnamon, stirred in thoroughly. Careful — it's easy to overdo these if making a single cup.</li> \n    <li>Replace the sugar with the flavored syrup of your choice. You can even buy liquid coffee essence or extract to add a bigger punch of coffee flavor. Keep in mind that commercial syrups often include high fructose corn syrup.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add coconut oil or butter to your coffee. Not everyone loves this trend, but you might change your mind when you're slogging through a jar of bad instant. After making your instant coffee, toss it in the blender with 1 tsp (5mL) coconut oil or butter and blend until frothy.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Better Tasting Instant Coffee Step 12 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/05/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-12-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Tea drinkers have a long-running argument over whether to pour in the milk or the hot water first. This decision can affect the flavor of your instant coffee too if you use a lot of milk. Try both to see which you prefer.</li> \n  <li>If you can't stand the instant coffee you've purchased to try, don't toss it away. It's great to use in cooking!</li> \n  <li>Different sugars taste quite different. Add raw or brown sugar to your coffee for a richer molasses flavor.</li> \n  <li>Pat yourself on the back for drinking instant coffee. It produces fewer carbon emissions than drip-filtered coffee!<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Ground coffee is a very different product. It will not dissolve in hot water, and stirring it in a cup will not extract the right flavors.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Froth-Milk-for-Cappuccino-Without-Fancy-Tools\" title=\"Froth Milk for Cappuccino Without Fancy Tools\">Froth Milk for Cappuccino Without Fancy Tools</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Roast-Coffee-Beans\" title=\"Roast Coffee Beans\">Roast Coffee Beans</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Instant-Coffee\" title=\"Make Instant Coffee\">Make Instant Coffee</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section:
