</li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 10 Mar 2022 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-1-Version-5.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-1-Version-5.jpg","linkMd5":"43460753c885488e1bfa942af13d3c37","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn44@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-14-55-661_395954e2903c55f0.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":56500,"destBytes":38236,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-1-Version-5.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-1-Version-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn44@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-14-55-661_395954e2903c55f0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b3/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-2-Version-5.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-2-Version-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn90@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-14-009_410d21c393a768a2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn21@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-10-425_ba787583e3f76499.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn50@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-11-396_167798511083ace1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-10-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn63@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-09-868_506fd2faa8d1b0fb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/05/Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid80768-v4-728px-Make-Better-Tasting-Instant-Coffee-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn65@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-11-046_c556b10e4e758722.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693948},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Treat an Itchy Scalp After Using Hair Dye","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Most hair dyes contain harsh chemicals that can cause minor irritation and scalp itchiness, as well as allergic reactions. If your scalp gets a bit itchy and red after using hair dye, you can likely relieve your symptoms at home by washing your scalp thoroughly or using a moisturizing compress or cream. If you also develop a rash or have any soreness or pain, your scalp itchiness may be caused by an allergic reaction to one or more of the hair dye ingredients. In most cases, you can alleviate your reaction symptoms with a steroid or antihistamine, although you may need to contact your doctor if your symptoms persist. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Relieving a Minor Itchy Scalp\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Relieving-a-Minor-Itchy-Scalp\">Relieving a Minor Itchy Scalp</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Wash your hair with a gentle shampoo to remove any excess dye. Pour a quarter-sized amount of a gentle shampoo, such as a baby shampoo, into your hands and rub it into your scalp and hair until it covers your whole head and gets very sudsy. Then, rinse the shampoo and excess hair dye out with cool to warm water.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-1-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Treat an Itchy Scalp After Using Hair Dye Step 1 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a1/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-1-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Leaving excess hair dye on your scalp and hair is one of the most common causes of itchy scalp after using hair dye. You may be able to stop the itchiness simply by washing your hair thoroughly.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>Look for shampoos that are labeled “gentle,” “all-natural,” or “free of harsh chemicals.” Harsh chemicals may react with the hair dye and make your scalp itchiness worse.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Rub a quarter-sized amount of 2% hydrogen peroxide into your scalp. Rinse the hydrogen peroxide out quickly so that it won’t affect your hair color. The hydrogen peroxide will oxidize the dye chemicals, which should stop the adverse reaction on your scalp.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Treat an Itchy Scalp After Using Hair Dye Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Even if you aren’t allergic to any ingredients in your hair dye, the harsh chemicals can still make your scalp itch. Using 2% hydrogen peroxide will help counteract the chemical reaction.</li> \n    <li>Hydrogen peroxide may start to lighten your hair color if you leave it on too long. Therefore, it’s important that you rinse it out as soon as you’ve rubbed it into your scalp.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hold a wet compress of olive oil and lime on your scalp. Saturate a disposable, damp towel or clean, old rag with olive oil. Then, squeeze the juice from a lime over the cloth and twist it to combine the juice and oil. Place the compress on your scalp until the itchiness starts to subside.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Treat an Itchy Scalp After Using Hair Dye Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>While an olive oil and lime compress doesn’t always help, it may help soothe your itchy skin and alleviate any skin tightness caused by the hair dye.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>If you have any inflammation or redness along with the itchiness, you can place the compress in the refrigerator for a few minutes to cool it and help calm your skin.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Apply an emollient moisturizing treatment to calm an itchy scalp. In many cases, the harsh chemicals in hair dye will dry out your scalp. Instructions will vary depending on the emollient type and brand you choose, but typically you’ll rub a generous layer of the cream over your scalp and leave it for several minutes before rinsing it with water.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Treat an Itchy Scalp After Using Hair Dye Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Emollient moisturizes are generally made to help soothe common inflammatory skin conditions, such as eczema. Because the symptoms of an itchy scalp after using hair dye can be similar, these treatments tend to work well.</li> \n    <li>Look for soothing ingredients like Argan oil, olive oil, Shea butter, and jojoba oil.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Alleviating an Allergic Reaction\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Alleviating-an-Allergic-Reaction\">Alleviating an Allergic Reaction</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Apply an over-the-counter steroid cream if your scalp is inflamed. Follow the instructions on the bottle and only use it as often as instructed. In most cases, allergic reactions to hair dye are minor, so you’ll likely be able to treat it at home with an over-the-counter steroid cream.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Treat an Itchy Scalp After Using Hair Dye Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If your symptoms are severe or persistent, you may need to get a prescription-strength steroid cream from your doctor.</li> \n    <li>If you have any pain or tenderness, a rash, or sores on your scalp after using hair dye, it’s likely that you’ve had an allergic reaction to an ingredient in the dye.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Take an over-the-counter oral antihistamine to help stop the itchiness. If your itchy scalp is caused by an allergic reaction to an ingredient in the hair dye, over-the-counter oral antihistamines like Benadryl can provide relief. Oral antihistamines generally start working within 1 hour.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-6-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Treat an Itchy Scalp After Using Hair Dye Step 6 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-6-Version-4.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-6-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Many oral antihistamines cause drowsiness, so make sure you use them as directed.</li> \n    <li>Depending on the severity of your reaction to the hair dye, your scalp may stop itching after 1 dose, or you may need to take several doses until the itching subsides.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>See your doctor if the itchiness continues for more than 2 days. If your symptoms, including itchiness, persists for over 2 days, make an appointment to see your doctor or get a referral to see an allergy specialist. Either your doctor or an allergy specialist can perform tests to assess what ingredient caused the reaction and determine how to treat it so your itchiness will subside.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Treat an Itchy Scalp After Using Hair Dye Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>In addition, make an appointment to see your doctor or an allergy specialist if your itchy scalp becomes inflamed or if you develop a rash.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Preventing an Itchy Scalp from Hair Dye\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Preventing-an-Itchy-Scalp-from-Hair-Dye\">Preventing an Itchy Scalp from Hair Dye</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Avoid using products with the same ingredients after a reaction. If you get an itchy scalp after using a particular type or brand of hair dye, take note of the ingredients so you can avoid using hair dyes with the same active chemicals in the future. Most hair dye reactions are caused by a chemical called paraphenylenediamine (PPD). Therefore, if your scalp gets itchy after using a hair dye containing PPD, avoid using these in the future.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-8-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Treat an Itchy Scalp After Using Hair Dye Step 8 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-8-Version-4.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-8-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>PPD is primarily found in dark colored hair dyes.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Dab hair dye behind your ear to spot test for an allergy. Before using a new hair dye or any hair dye that contains PPD, dab a small amount of the dye on your scalp just behind your ear. If your skin starts to itch or get swollen and red, it’s likely that you’re allergic to PPD or another ingredient in the dye and will get an itchy scalp if you use it.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-9-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Treat an Itchy Scalp After Using Hair Dye Step 9 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/58/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-9-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you’re getting your hair dyed at a salon, you can ask your stylist to perform this test as well.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Leave dye on your hair for the time recommended in the instructions. If you’re trying to cover stubborn greys or dye your hair a drastically different color, it can be tempting to leave the hair dye on for longer than instructed on the box or bottle.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup> Even if you aren’t allergic to the hair dye, this can cause your scalp to itch! Never leave dye on longer than instructed.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-10-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Treat an Itchy Scalp After Using Hair Dye Step 10 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-10-Version-4.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-10-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Most at-home hair dyes should be left on for 10 to 45 minutes. Always check the instructions, though, to make sure you don’t leave the dye on for too long.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap href=\"https://healthfully.com/allergic-reaction-to-hair-dye-head-itching-8183927.html\">https://healthfully.com/allergic-reaction-to-hair-dye-head-itching-8183927.html</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_ref-9\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hair-dye-reactions/\">https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hair-dye-reactions/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_ref-10\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.aad.org/itchy-skin/relieve-scalp-itch\">https://www.aad.org/itchy-skin/relieve-scalp-itch</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.insider.com/how-to-treat-allergic-reaction-to-hair-dye-chemical-ppd-2019-8\">https://www.insider.com/how-to-treat-allergic-reaction-to-hair-dye-chemical-ppd-2019-8</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_ref-12\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\">[v161865_b01]. 3 August 2021.</span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye#_ref-13\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"https://www.insider.com/how-to-treat-allergic-reaction-to-hair-dye-chemical-ppd-2019-8\">https://www.insider.com/how-to-treat-allergic-reaction-to-hair-dye-chemical-ppd-2019-8</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 12 Mar 2022 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a1/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-1-Version-4.jpg","linkMd5":"54a82f6b78b5e342df8a16c9e6629b91","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn9@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-14-55-072_5c0e0644a6ccb2d7.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":51922,"destBytes":29408,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a1/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-1-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn9@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-14-55-072_5c0e0644a6ccb2d7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn66@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-12-032_ca46d306ee3803bb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn53@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-09-954_fcfc5da4bf5cbc0a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/07/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn20@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-13-556_31ac1dee6cb1c83e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-6-Version-4.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-6-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn28@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-13-084_5f084ffc642f5c99.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn99@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-11-992_ac2e6e57e8407871.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-8-Version-4.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-8-Version-4.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/58/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-9-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn7@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-11-758_b2ca115b97e38b79.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-10-Version-4.jpg/aid11624485-v4-728px-Treat-an-Itchy-Scalp-After-Using-Hair-Dye-Step-10-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn76@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-13-489_d7d68e361e76fad0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693943},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Curl Ribbon","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Curl-Ribbon","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>There are a variety of ways to curl ribbon, whether it's a curling ribbon for a package or a bit of fabric ribbon for a hair clip. You can curl a curling ribbon with just a pair of scissors. Fabric ribbon, on the other hand, needs to be baked, or have a starch solution applied to it. Either way, it isn't that hard! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Curl-Ribbon&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Curl-Ribbon&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Using Curling Ribbon\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-Curling-Ribbon\">Using Curling Ribbon</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Cut your curling ribbon to the desired length. If you're not sure, cut about 12 inches (about 30 centimeters). If this isn't long enough, you can cut off a longer piece. Remember that when you curl a ribbon it will get shorter, so take that into account.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Curl-Ribbon#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Curl-Ribbon-Step-1-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Curl Ribbon Step 1 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Curl-Ribbon-Step-1-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-1-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Find the natural curl of the ribbon. Even when the curling ribbon hasn't been curled, it will have a natural curl to it. You will want to follow that natural curl when you're using the scissors to curl it.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Curl-Ribbon#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Curl-Ribbon-Step-2-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Curl Ribbon Step 2 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Curl-Ribbon-Step-2-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-2-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Note which side is shiny and which is dull. The dull side will need to face downwards, towards the ground, when you're curling the ribbon with scissors. Typically the curl follows the shinier side of the ribbon.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Curl-Ribbon#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Curl-Ribbon-Step-3-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Curl Ribbon Step 3 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Curl-Ribbon-Step-3-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-3-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Grasp one end of the ribbon between your forefinger and thumb. You want to pull this as taut as possible. It depends on whether you've already tied it to a package, or whether you're going to do that after you've curled the ribbon.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Curl-Ribbon#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Curl-Ribbon-Step-4-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Curl Ribbon Step 4 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Curl-Ribbon-Step-4-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-4-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It's easier to tie the ribbon on the package and then curl it because then you only have to grip it on one end. Otherwise, you have to tape down one end to hold it in place.</li> \n    <li>If you're right-handed, place the ribbon in your left hand, and vice versa if you're left-handed.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Hold the scissors upward, with the blades facing up and open. Wrap your fingers around the middle of the blades and handles (in the X that's created when the scissors are opened up). Your thumb should be holding the ribbon against the sharpened edge of the scissors\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Curl-Ribbon-Step-5-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Curl Ribbon Step 5 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Curl-Ribbon-Step-5-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-5-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Press the dull underside of the ribbon firmly against the blade of the scissors with your thumb. Make sure that the ribbon is still facing dull side down.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Pull the ribbon across the scissors blade while continuing to press with your thumb. You need to make sure that you do this quickly. The pressure will cause the ribbon to curl.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Curl-Ribbon#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>you must do this part quickly because if you do it too slow the ribbon won't curl. In some cases, it will get flatter.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Release the ribbon from the scissors blade. The curling ribbon should spiral up. If it doesn't or isn't as curly as you want it to be, then you can try the procedure again. If it doesn't work a second time, then you'll need to get a new length of ribbon and try again.<br /><br /></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Curl-Ribbon&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Curling Fabric Ribbon With Starch Solution\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Curling-Fabric-Ribbon-With-Starch-Solution\">Curling Fabric Ribbon With Starch Solution</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Gather your materials. Although you need more materials than you would if you used a simple curling ribbon, this procedure doesn't take that long to accomplish. Fabric ribbons that you've taken the time to curl can add something a little extra to a nice package.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Curl-Ribbon#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Curl-Ribbon-Step-9-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Curl Ribbon Step 9 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Curl-Ribbon-Step-9-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-9-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Find a dowel stick (pencil or rod works, too) which you'll use to curl the ribbon around. A bigger diameter creates a bigger curl, while a smaller diameter creates a smaller curl.</li> \n    <li>Get a length of fabric ribbon. The width doesn't particularly matter, it just depends on what you want in terms of width. Make it a few inches (or centimeters) longer than the final desired length because curling will make it smaller.</li> \n    <li>Mix cornstarch and water in a spray bottle.</li> \n    <li>Grab a couple of clothespins or clips or use tape.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Mix one tablespoon of cornstarch powder with one-pint water. You'll slosh the mixture around in the spray bottle until you've made sure that the cornstarch has completely dissolved.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Curl-Ribbon#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Clip fabric ribbon to one end of your dowel. You'll do this with the clothespin or the clip, or you can tape it. Make sure that the ribbon is secured, because if it comes undone during the drying period, it won't curl very well.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Wind ribbon around dowel. When you're doing this you want to make it as tight or as loose as you want your curls to be. Again, depending on the diameter of the dowel stick (or whatever rod you're using) the curls will be bigger or smaller. Don't overlap the ribbon as you're winding it or those parts won't get the starch spray.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Tape or clip the end of the ribbon in place, so that it is secured on both sides.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Spray ribbon with cornstarch solution. Don't drown the ribbon in the solution, but make sure that the entire ribbon is completely coated. Any parts that aren't coated completely won't be stiff enough to maintain their shape.<br /><br /></li> \n  <li>Allow your ribbons to dry. They have to be completely dry before you remove them from the dowel, because otherwise, they may lose their shape. This can take a while so it's a good idea to curl your ribbons with plenty of time to spare before you need to use them.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Curl-Ribbon-Step-14-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Curl Ribbon Step 14 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Curl-Ribbon-Step-14-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-14-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Remove clothespins and slide the ribbon off the dowel. Your ribbon should be stiff and curling. You can somewhat manipulate the shape if you need to attach it to a package, but don't let it get wet, because that will make it lose its curls.<br /><br /></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Curl-Ribbon&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Curling Fabric Ribbon by Baking Them\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Curling-Fabric-Ribbon-by-Baking-Them\">Curling Fabric Ribbon by Baking Them</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Gather supplies. Unlike curling fabric ribbons with a starch solution, you'll need a few more supplies and a little more time, because it can take a little bit of time to bake the ribbons into curls than to simply allow them to dry. This method, however, tends to leave them less stiff than the cornstarch method.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Curl-Ribbon#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Curl-Ribbon-Step-16-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Curl Ribbon Step 16 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Curl-Ribbon-Step-16-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-16-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Get your fabric ribbon. When it curls it is smaller than what you started with so always cut off a bit more than you think you need.</li> \n    <li>Grab some wooden dowels or skewers to wind the ribbons around.</li> \n    <li>Get clothespins to hold the ribbons in place.</li> \n    <li>Use a spray bottle with water to spray everything before baking it.</li> \n    <li>Line a cookie sheet with tinfoil on which to bake your ribbons.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wind your ribbons around the skewers and secure them. You want to make sure that the ribbons are tight enough that they won't slip off or lose their shape when you bake them. Avoid overlapping them so that the water gets every part of the ribbon.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Secure ribbons on both ends of skewers with clothespins.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Spray the ribbons with water. You don't have the soak the ribbons, but give them a good spray and make sure that you're getting all parts of the ribbon. This will make it so they don't burn while in the oven.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Spray the clothespins as well, so they don't burn when they're in the oven either.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Bake ribbons for about 10 minutes at 200 degrees Fahrenheit. Place the ribbons on the tinfoil lined cookie sheet. The timing depends on your oven, so if it needs to go a little longer that's okay.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Curl-Ribbon-Step-19-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Curl Ribbon Step 19 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/71/Curl-Ribbon-Step-19-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-19-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>That would be about 93 degrees Celsius.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Remove from oven when the ribbon is completely dry. Keep checking while it's baking so that you don't over or under-bake the ribbon or ribbons. When the ribbons are completely dry, that's when you take it out of the oven.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Curl-Ribbon-Step-20-Version-6.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Curl Ribbon Step 20 Version 6.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Curl-Ribbon-Step-20-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-20-Version-6.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Check underneath to make sure that it is completely dry on all sides.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Take ribbon off dowel when it is cool. Your ribbon should be well curled It should retain this shape unless it gets wet. You can use it to decorate a hair clip, or add it to a lovely package for that little extra touch!<br /><br /></li>\n </ol> \n <p><br /> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Curl-Ribbon&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Pressing harder on one edge of the ribbon as you pull it across the scissors will curl it more tightly.</li> \n  <li>It helps to pay close attention when having your gifts wrapped professionally at gift-wrapping counters; watch the method used by the wrappers to curl the ribbon as they're adept at it. You might even ask them to show you how to do it.</li> \n  <li>If the ribbon didn't curl properly the first time, repeat the procedure, making sure to use the scissors blade on the same side to strengthen the curl.</li> \n  <li>Curl multiple pieces of curling ribbon and attach with a piece of wire in the middle; affix to any gift package.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Curl-Ribbon&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Use care with the scissors when cutting or when pressing your thumb against the blade to curl the ribbon.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Curl-Ribbon&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Wrap-a-Present\" title=\"Wrap a Present\">Wrap a Present</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Holiday-Wreath\" title=\"Make a Holiday Wreath\">Make a Holiday Wreath</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" free\" href=\"https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/secret-of-ribbon-curling/\">https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/secret-of-ribbon-curling/</a></span> </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-6\"><a </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 08 Mar 2022 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Curl-Ribbon-Step-1-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-1-Version-6.jpg","linkMd5":"5691032f27e58cf2346cbe863e1471ed","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn27@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-54-901_48d34dedac542492.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":32251,"destBytes":19910,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/12/Curl-Ribbon-Step-1-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-1-Version-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn27@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-54-901_48d34dedac542492.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Curl-Ribbon-Step-2-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-2-Version-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn99@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-13-405_e0f73ab3f70da530.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Curl-Ribbon-Step-3-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-3-Version-6.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Curl-Ribbon-Step-4-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-4-Version-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn8@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-09-248_73646c01e48f39a7.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cb/Curl-Ribbon-Step-5-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-5-Version-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn26@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-12-860_4e6cf3e583f1940c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/41/Curl-Ribbon-Step-9-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-9-Version-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn60@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-13-751_74a9746f411f6272.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Curl-Ribbon-Step-14-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-14-Version-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn33@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-11-688_63ca1d8229979781.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Curl-Ribbon-Step-16-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-16-Version-6.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/71/Curl-Ribbon-Step-19-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-19-Version-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn45@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-10-289_bcab60819da6ac77.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Curl-Ribbon-Step-20-Version-6.jpg/aid97435-v4-728px-Curl-Ribbon-Step-20-Version-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn62@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-11-977_abbb3acc5d810046.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693971},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Remove Long Wearing Lipstick","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Because the purpose of long-wearing lipstick is for it to remain on your lips, removing it requires a little more effort than standard lipstick or other kinds of makeup. Using makeup removal techniques specifically designed for your lips and beauty products you likely already have in your home, you will be able to remove your long wearing lipstick without frustration and without rubbing your lips raw. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Prepping Your Lips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Prepping-Your-Lips\">Prepping Your Lips</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Blot as much lipstick as possible. Long wearing lip colors are nearly impossible to simply wipe off. However, before you begin the removal process, blot or wipe off as much lip color as you can using a tissue or cotton makeup remover pad.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-1-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 1 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a4/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-1-Version-4.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-1-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Swipe on some lip balm. Depending on the lasting power of your long wear lipstick, lip balm might work to remove some or all of your lipstick. Apply a heavy coat of lip balm to your lips and wait a minute or two for it to soak in. Then, work in firm circular motions as you use a cotton pad or paper towel to rub the color away.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-2-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 2 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-2-Version-4.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-2-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Exfoliate your lips. With the lip balm still on your lips, wet a soft-bristled toothbrush and gently scrub your lips in a circular motion. Be sure to do this very lightly so you don’t hurt your lips.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-3-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 3 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bc/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-3-Version-4.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-3-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The combinations of lip balm and lightly brushing your lips with the toothbrush will help loosen the long wearing lipstick.</li> \n    <li>If the lip balm and exfoliating method is going to work, it will start working almost immediately. Don't keep scrubbing your lips if this method isn't working on your particular lip color. You can hurt your lips, making them sore or cracked.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Wipe your lips with a warm washcloth. This won’t remove a waterproof lip color. However, it will “loosen” the color on your lips, which will help your makeup removal products be more effective at removing the color.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-4-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 4 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-4-Version-4.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-4-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Rinse the washcloth and repeat. If you notice that the warm washcloth seems to be working to remove your lipstick, then rinse the washcloth with warm water and again gently wipe your lips. Rinsing the washcloth will help you avoid smearing the lip color to other parts of your face.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-5-Version-5.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 5 Version 5.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-5-Version-5.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-5-Version-5.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Removing the Lip Color\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Removing-the-Lip-Color\">Removing the Lip Color</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Apply petroleum jelly. Petroleum jelly is one of many products that you can use to create a hydrating “mask” that will loosen even stubborn lipsticks. Apply a thick layer to your lips. Be sure to leave the jelly on your lips for at least five minutes to let it soak in and work on the lipstick color before you use a cotton makeup remover pad or a paper towel to wipe it off.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Try coconut oil. Much like petroleum jelly, coconut oil will create a hydrating layer over your lipstick that will help loosen it and make it easier to wipe off. Both coconut oil and petroleum jelly accomplish the same things, so it’s up to you as to which one you prefer to use. Wipe thin layers of coconut oil onto your lips, and let it soak in for a least five minutes to loosen the lip color. Then, wipe it off with a paper towel or a cotton makeup remover pad.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 7 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-7-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Because of its consistency, be aware that coconut oil can run and will be somewhat messier than petroleum jelly.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Try eye makeup remover. Although this will dry your lips out more than coconut oil or petroleum jelly, standard eye makeup removal products will often do the trick on stubborn long wear lipsticks. Eye makeup remover will be especially effective if you prep your lips first by applying lip balm and then exfoliating. Put the eye makeup remover on a cotton pad or paper towel and wipe over lips, repeating if needed.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 8 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-8-Version-2.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-8-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Avoid getting eye makeup remover in your mouth because it's only designed for external use.</li> \n    <li>Wash your lips with a gentle cleanser after using the makeup remover. Pat dry and apply lip balm to return some moisture to your lips.</li> \n    <li>Try an oil-based cleanser to remove long-lasting lipstick. You just rub it onto your lips, then when you add water, it becomes a milky consistency and turns into a cleanser.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Give face or body lotion a try. Sometimes when you’re on the go, you might not have access to coconut oil, petroleum jelly, or a proper makeup remover. Lotions can serve as makeup removers in a pinch. While lotions might be better suited to removing eye makeup and foundation/face powders, they will be helpful if you have none of the other options handy. Apply the lotion to your lips and then use a makeup remover pad or paper towel to remove it.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 9 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b0/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-9-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Be careful to avoid getting the lotion in your mouth. Only apply it to the outside of your mouth.</li> \n    <li>After removing the lipstick, carefully wipe off any excess lotion, wash your lips with a gentle cleanser, and then thoroughly pat your lips dry.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Restoring Moisture to Your Lips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Restoring-Moisture-to-Your-Lips\">Restoring Moisture to Your Lips</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Stay hydrated. Aside from applying products externally to your lips, staying hydrated will keep your lips from drying and cracking. The more hydrated your lips are, the smoother your lipstick will look and the easier it will come off. If you find yourself with dry, flaky lips, try increasing the amount of water you drink.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 10 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-10-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Try carrying a refillable water bottle with you throughout the day. In addition to being good for your overall health, staying hydrated can help with skin and lip health by improving circulation.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Use a lip scrub. You can easily <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Tasty-Lip-Scrub\" title=\"Make a Tasty Lip Scrub\">Make a Tasty Lip Scrub</a> with sugar, honey, and olive oil. Mixing these three ingredients will help moisturize your lips and remove dry, dead skin cells.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 11 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-11-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>To make a basic lip scrub at home, mix together brown sugar and lemon, then rub that on your lips to exfoliate them.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup></li> \n    <li>If you decide to make a larger batch of lip scrub, be sure to store it in an airtight container with a lid so your scrub doesn't dry out.</li> \n    <li>If you prefer, you can add different scents like vanilla to your lip scrub to get the exact scent/taste that you like.</li> \n    <li>Add your lip scrub to your evening routine right after you brush your teeth. Making lip exfoliation part of your daily routine will keep your lips healthy and hydrated. Experts recommend using a scrub at least once per week and more often if you have very dry lips.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Apply a thick lip moisturizer to chapped lips. Apply an unscented, unflavored <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Cocoa-Lip-Balm\" title=\"Make Cocoa Lip Balm\">lip balm</a> or lip moisturizer that contains a mixture of moisturizers and wax to your dry, chapped lips. This should help to restore moisture to your lips and to protect them. Reapply as needed.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-12-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 12 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-12-Version-3.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-12-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Overuse of lip balms can interfere with your lips’ natural ability to produce moisture. Instead of using a lip balm daily, stop using it once your lips heal, and only use it again when your lips are chapped and dry. This applies to medicated lip balms as well, which usually contain topical steroids.</li> \n    <li>Try applying a generous amount of lip balm to your lips when you start your makeup routine. Then, just before you're ready to put on your lipstick, wipe away the excess lip balm. That will leave your lips soft and smooth, even if you're wearing a matte, longwear lipstick.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Avoid wearing only flat, matte long wear lipsticks. Matte long wear lip colors are often extremely drying and difficult to remove. If you love the look of these lipsticks, try alternating them with lipsticks advertised as “hydrating.” It’s easier to remove lipstick from hydrated lips than dry, flaky ones.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you choose matte long wear lip colors, be sure to thoroughly hydrate your lips before applying the lip color. Look for a natural lip balm with aloe and vitamin E in it. These components in natural lip balms protect and hydrate your lips without creating a sheen on your lips that can interfere with applying matte lipsticks.</li> \n    <li>If you’ve been wearing a matte long wear lipstick and your lips feel dry at the end of the day, try applying a thin layer of coconut oil to them after you’ve removed the lipstick and before bed. This way, the coconut oil can hydrate your lips overnight.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Avoid rubbing your lips raw. If you have an especially stubborn lip color that won’t come off easily, then you might need to give your lips a rest between removal attempts. Don’t scrub your lips so much that they feel raw.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Remove Long Wearing Lipstick Step 14 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dc/Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid666682-v4-728px-Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick-Step-14-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Lipstick remover exists that is specifically designed for removing long-wearing lipstick. While expensive, this might be a good investment for you if you wear long wearing lipstick every day.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Don’t use cotton balls to wipe off makeup removal products, as this can get sticky and messy.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: What You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"What-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"What-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">What You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Sugar</li> \n  <li>Honey</li> \n  <li>Olive oil</li> \n  <li>Coconut oil</li> \n  <li>Petroleum jelly</li> \n  <li>Eye makeup remover</li> \n  <li>Makeup removal pads</li> \n  <li>Lip moisturizer</li> \n  <li>Face lotion</li> \n  <li>Washcloth</li> \n  <li>Soft-bristled toothbrush</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Remove-Long-Wearing-Lipstick&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <p><a target=\"_blank\"
