id=\"_note-31\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Freeze-Bacon#_ref-31\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://www.stilltasty.com/fooditems/index/16431\">http://www.stilltasty.com/fooditems/index/16431</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 08 Mar 2022 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Freeze-Bacon-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"677cc2e754b1750c50f601bd2d218f04","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn41@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-14-54-975_43bc86cbf273dd1d.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":80704,"destBytes":55312,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Freeze-Bacon-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn41@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-14-54-975_43bc86cbf273dd1d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Freeze-Bacon-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Freeze-Bacon-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn22@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-11-188_024b7234c40a81fd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7e/Freeze-Bacon-Step-9-Version-2.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-9-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn47@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-13-807_7eb4f2a8abf5a453.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/dd/Freeze-Bacon-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-11-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn55@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-09-268_e8d00eed3b28aa3e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9e/Freeze-Bacon-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-12-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn42@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-11-446_ba9ffbabf7c40648.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/68/Freeze-Bacon-Step-14-Version-2.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-14-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn4@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-13-426_7349f87861a69c3a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Freeze-Bacon-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-17-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn96@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-12-131_b41a904f008ce2bf.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Freeze-Bacon-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-19-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn72@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-09-380_50b73d1e00062ff4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/90/Freeze-Bacon-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-20-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn82@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-10-805_07ce8d749ce953b2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Freeze-Bacon-Step-21-Version-2.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-21-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn34@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-11-013_c41b4c880a1134bf.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5f/Freeze-Bacon-Step-22-Version-2.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-22-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn12@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-11-546_483e4f6fb9949298.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1e/Freeze-Bacon-Step-23-Version-2.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-23-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn82@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-10-037_50685859a1f8a8c8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/76/Freeze-Bacon-Step-24-Version-2.jpg/aid39660-v4-728px-Freeze-Bacon-Step-24-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn42@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-12-110_9bf941f1c5871288.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693978},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Make Sweet Potato Fries","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Sweet potato fries are a fun, sweet alternative to standard French fries. These tubers are also slightly more nutritious than their more ordinary counterparts. While both have similar amounts of calories and carbohydrates, sweet potatoes are loaded with antioxidants like beta-carotene, vitamin C, and vitamin E, to name a few. Sweet potatoes also have a lower glycemic index, so they do not raise blood sugar levels quite as high. All of this combined means that the sweet potato fry is a worthwhile alternative to try.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ingredients\">Ingredients</span></h2>\n<ul><li>3 large sweet potatoes, about 2 lbs. (900 g)</li>\n<li>1/4 cup (60 ml) olive oil</li>\n<li>2 Tbsp (28.3 g) brown sugar</li>\n<li>1 Tbsp (14.3 g) salt</li>\n<li>1 Tbsp (14.3 g) pepper</li>\n<li>1/2 tsp (2.4 g) paprika</li>\n<li>1/2 tsp (2.4 g) cinnamon</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Servings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Servings\">Servings</span></h2>\n<ul><li>3 to 6 servings<span id=\"peel\"></span></li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Preparation\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Preparation\">Preparation</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Peel the sweet potatoes. Place the blade of a sharp knife or vegetable peeler at the top of on sweet potato and drag it down the length of the potato peeler, applying just enough even pressure to remove the skin. Continue peeling off strips of skin until the entire potato is skinless. Repeat with the other two potatoes.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Sweet Potato Fries Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Use a sharp knife to cut the ends off your sweet potatoes. Do not cut off much; a small 1/4-inch to 1/2-inch (1/2 to 1 1/4-centimeter) slice on both ends of a potato should suffice. Doing so will prevent your fries from having small, pointy tips, which is important because these little pointed tips tend to burn quickly and taste bad.<span id=\"chop\"></span><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Cut the sweet potatoes in half lengthwise. Use a sharp knife to cut each sweet potato into two equal halves, cutting from the top tip to the bottom, leaving you with six halves.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Cut the halves into quarters. Use a sharp knife to cut each half in half crosswise, cutting from side to side instead of from top to bottom.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Slice the quarters into equal wedges. Each wedge should ideally be around 1/4-inch (1/2-centimeter) thick and 1/4-inch (1/2-centimeter) wide, but the length of the wedges can vary depending on personal preference. Wedges between 3 and 4 inches (7 1/2 to 10 centimeters) in length are usually a pretty good size. Regardless of what you choose, however, try to keep the majority of your wedges uniform in size.<br /><br />\n<ul><li>Note that you can also use a crinkle cut knife to produce crinkle cut sweet potato fries. Similarly, you can use a knife or mandolin to cut the sweet potatoes into disks.<span id=\"preheat\"></span></li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Baking\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Baking\">Baking</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Preheat the oven to 450 degrees Fahrenheit (232 degrees Celsius). Prepare a shallow baking sheet by spraying it with vegetable spray or by covering it with non-stick aluminum foil or parchment paper.<span id=\"spices\"></span><div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Sweet Potato Fries Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Place the sweet potato wedges into a large bowl and add the oil. Mix the wedges into the oil using your hands or a large wooden or plastic baking spoon. Keeping mixing until you can see that each wedge is coated in oil.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Sprinkle the sugar over your fries. If you are on a low-sugar diet, you can skip this step, but sugar does enhance the sweetness of the sweet potatoes. Sugar also helps to caramelize the fries.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Sprinkle the salt, pepper, paprika, and cinnamon over your fries. Salt and pepper are fairly standard, but you can leave out the paprika and cinnamon if either taste does not appeal to you. Try to sprinkle your spices over the top of your fries evenly to make mixing them easier.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Mix the sugar, spices, and the sweet potato wedges. You can use your hands, but you may find that your hands attract the oily spices, robbing your fries of them. Instead, use a plastic or wooden baking spoon to reduce the amount of spices lost during the mixing process. By the time you finish mixing, you should be able to see spices coating each wedge.<span id=\"sheet\"></span><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Spread the wedges out onto your prepared baking sheet. Spread them out into a single layer. Fries that overlap one another will not cook evenly, so if you have too many fries to fit onto one baking sheet, it is better to use a second baking sheet than to allow your fries to pile up.<span id=\"bake\"></span><br /><br /></li>\n<li>Bake your fries in the prepared oven for about 15 minutes. At this point, the tops should begin to look slightly browned. Take the fries out and flip them with a flat spatula or hamburger flipper before returning them to the oven and baking for another 5 to 15 minutes.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Remove the fries when they look well browned. Test one of the fries by breaking it open. The inside should be fairly tender. You can taste one to determine its doneness, but make sure that it has some chance to cool before doing so to prevent your mouth from getting burned.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-13-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Sweet Potato Fries Step 13 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/81/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-13-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Allow the fries to cool for 5 to 10 minutes. Serve them hot as a side dish or snack.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Sweet Potato Fries Step 14 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Deep Frying\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Deep-Frying\">Deep Frying</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Boil water in a 5-quart (5-liter) pot. Heat the water over medium-high heat.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-15-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Sweet Potato Fries Step 15 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-15-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-15-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Dunk the sweet potato wedges in the boiling water. Cover the pot and allow the wedges to boil for 10 minutes before removing them. Pat the sweet potatoes dry with a clean towel or paper towels.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Fill a 5-quart (5-liter) deep fryer or Dutch oven with oil. Leave only 3 inches (7.6 centimeters) of empty space in between the surface of the oil and the rim of the fryer. Heat the oil to a temperature of 300 degrees Fahrenheit (148.9 degrees Celsius).<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-17-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Sweet Potato Fries Step 17 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-17-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-17-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Add a handful of sweet potato wedges to the hot oil. Fry the wedges for 3 to 4 minutes or until they just begin to brown.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Remove the wedges from the oil with a slotted spoon. Set the sweet potato fries on several layers of paper towel. The paper towel absorbs some of the oil, helping the fries drain. Allow the wedges to cool for at least 10 minutes, but do not keep them for more than 2 hours.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Repeat the frying and draining process with the remaining wedges. Only fry a handful of sweet potato wedges at one time.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-20-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Sweet Potato Fries Step 20 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-20-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-20-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Reheat the oil to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) when ready to serve. By this point, the fries should have cooled off significantly and need to be re-fried to heat. Even if the sweet potato fries have not cooled completely, you should still re-fry them to finish cooking them.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-21-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Sweet Potato Fries Step 21 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-21-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-21-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Drop your fries into the oil a handful at a time. Cook the fries in the oil for an addition minute until they puff up. Continue re-frying handfuls of sweet potato wedges until you have finished the entire batch.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Remove the fries from the oil using a slotted spoon. Drain them on dry paper towels for one minute.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Combine the sugar, salt, pepper, paprika, and cinnamon in a large bowl. Toss the seasonings together to thoroughly combine them.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Add your sweet potato fries to the seasoning bowl. Gently toss the fries or shift the bowl around until the fries are thoroughly coated.<br /><br /></li>\n<li>Remove your fries from the bowl and set them on a platter. Serve the sweet potato fries as a side dish or snack.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-26-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Sweet Potato Fries Step 26 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-26-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-26-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>You can also try other spice combinations instead of using paprika and cinnamon. Garlic powder will give you more savory fries, while pumpkin pie spice will impart a richer, sweeter taste. Chipotle powder or Chinese five-spice will create a spicier batch of sweet potato fries.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Things You&#039;ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Baking sheet</li>\n<li>Non-stick aluminum foil or parchment paper</li>\n<li>Sharp knife</li>\n<li>Vegetable peeler</li>\n<li>Large bowl</li>\n<li>Plastic or wooden baking spoon</li>\n<li>5-quart (5-liter) pot</li>\n<li>5-quart (5-liter) deep fryer or Dutch oven</li>\n<li>Paper towels</li>\n<li>Slotted spoon</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2>\n<ul><li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cook-a-Sweet-Potato-in-the-Microwave\" title=\"Cook a Sweet Potato in the Microwave\">Cook a Sweet Potato in the Microwave</a></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-French-Fries\" title=\"Make French Fries\">Make French Fries</a></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Homestyle-French-Fries\" title=\"Make Homestyle French Fries\">Make Homestyle French Fries</a></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-Sweet-Potato-Fries\" title=\"Cut Sweet Potato Fries\">Cut Sweet Potato Fries</a></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Season-Sweet-Potato-Fries\" title=\"Season Sweet Potato Fries\">Season Sweet Potato Fries</a></li></ul>\n<p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n<ul><li><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://www.simplyrecipes.com/recipes/oven_baked_sweet_potato_fries/\">Simply Recipes: Oven Baked Sweet Potato Fries</a></li>\n<li><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jul/01/news/la-heb-sweet-potatoes-weight-gain-201100701\">Los Angeles Times: Sweet potatoes vs. white potatoes - Are both bad for the waistline?</a></li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries&#38;action=edit&#38;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Quick Summary\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Quick-Summary\">Quick Summary</span></h2>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 07 Mar 2022 08:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"04cca96d98d40b303dac6e0a63e4d3d3","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn36@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-14-54-955_60efe177706e05cf.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":410,"sourceBytes":54105,"destBytes":35078,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn36@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-14-54-955_60efe177706e05cf.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn53@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-11-951_4d4f46d72fbdcca0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/81/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-13-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn52@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-09-507_425c403b858cfb99.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-14-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn94@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-14-361_7fc2d82b06c0bf81.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ac/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-15-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-15-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn20@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-09-663_199fc15c2a69b21a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c1/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-17-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-17-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn53@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-10-853_b82e3bd12bd7b5f5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/20/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-20-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-20-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn85@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-13-871_1b4e177c0a727da6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-21-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-21-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn62@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-10-639_6cfd34ce3604660e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-26-Version-3.jpg/aid2259684-v4-728px-Make-Sweet-Potato-Fries-Step-26-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn54@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-12-860_1318a4ca0c4ebc41.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693958},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Use Jojoba Oil to Enhance Dry Hair","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Jojoba oil comes from an herb that grows in the middle of the desert. This amazing oil is usually used to treat and condition hair and skin. If your hair is dry and damaged try incorporating jojoba oil into your beauty routine. You’ll have glowing, beautiful locks in no time! </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Applying Jojoba Oil as a Leave-In Treatment\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Applying-Jojoba-Oil-as-a-Leave-In-Treatment\">Applying Jojoba Oil as a Leave-In Treatment</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Purchase jojoba oil. Jojoba oil can be found at specialty herbal shops, beauty supply stores, and nicer grocery stores. Most stores stock it in the skincare section. Look for pure jojoba oil instead of beauty products with jojoba oil in them. If you’re having trouble finding it ask a store associate for help.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use Jojoba Oil to Enhance Dry Hair Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Alternatively, you can use argan oil for moisturizing dry hair without making it look greasy.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Determine how often you will treat your hair. If your hair is damaged and dry, start by doing a leave-in treatment once a week. If your hair is dry but not very damaged, do a treatment every two or three weeks. If you start to notice that your hair looks limp and oily, do the treatments less often. Inversely, if your hair still seems dry, do the treatments more often.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use Jojoba Oil to Enhance Dry Hair Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you do too many treatments and your hair looks oily, shampoo your hair to remove the excess oil.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Apply the oil to your scalp. First, dip your fingertips into the bowl of oil. Next, massage the oil into your scalp. Make sure to cover the easy-to-miss spots behind your ears and at the nape of your neck. Focus on covering every inch of your scalp and the first half-inch of hair growth.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use Jojoba Oil to Enhance Dry Hair Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Bend over forward to reach your roots more easily.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Apply the oil to your ends. Once your scalp is saturated with oil, apply it to the rest of your hair. Pour out some jojoba oil into your palm and work it into your hair. Apply a thick coat from roots to tips. Depending on how thick your hair is, you may need to use more jojoba oil than you might expect.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use Jojoba Oil to Enhance Dry Hair Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When in doubt, use more jojoba oil than you think you’ll need. It’s better to apply too much than not enough.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Let the treatment soak into your hair before washing. You can leave the oil treatment in your hair from 20 minutes to overnight. The longer you leave the treatment in your hair the more time the oil will have to soften your dry locks. Next, wash your hair normally. If you have a lot of trouble washing out the oil you may have to shampoo your hair twice.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use Jojoba Oil to Enhance Dry Hair Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you leave the treatment in your hair overnight, wear a shower cap to protect your pillowcase from oil stains.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Washing your Hair with Jojoba Oil\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Washing-your-Hair-with-Jojoba-Oil\">Washing your Hair with Jojoba Oil</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Mix the oil with shampoo or conditioner. If you want a daily moisture boost, try mixing jojoba oil with your favorite shampoo or conditioner. First, pour a small amount of shampoo or conditioner into a small bowl. Next, add a few drops of jojoba oil. Mix the ingredients together with a spoon until they’re completely blended. Wash your hair and style it normally.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use Jojoba Oil to Enhance Dry Hair Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The more damaged your hair is, the more jojoba oil you should add. Experiment with different amounts to see what works for you.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make your own jojoba oil conditioner. Mix together a 1 ¼ teaspoon of Guar gum, ¾ teaspoon jojoba oil, and a cup of distilled water into a bottle. A few drops of other nourishing mineral oils such as lavender and sandalwood can be added as well. Shake the bottle well to combine the ingredients. Use the mixture as a conditioner after shampooing.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use Jojoba Oil to Enhance Dry Hair Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Guar gum can be purchased at most herbal shops, nicer grocery stores, and online.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Make your own jojoba oil shampoo. First, make a tea by boiling ½ cup distilled water and 2 tablespoons of dried peppermint leaves and letting it steep for 20 minutes. Strain the tea and pour it into a large bottle. Mix in ¼ cup of liquid castile soap, 2 tablespoons vegetable glycerin, ½ teaspoon jojoba oil, and ½ teaspoon of honey. Shake the bottle well to combine the ingredients.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Use Jojoba Oil to Enhance Dry Hair Step 8 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Liquid castile soap and vegetable glycerin can be found in boutique herbal shops, larger grocery stores, and online.</li> \n    <li>If you can’t find dried peppermint leaves, substitute herbal peppermint tea. Just be sure that the only ingredient is peppermint.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Jojoba oil can be used to cure a dry scalp and repair damaged hair. It has also been shown to stimulate new hair growth.</li> \n  <li>Add other mineral oils to your jojoba oil to improve the scent and increase the nourishing properties.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Use-Coconut-Oil-on-Your-Hair-and-Skin\" title=\"Use Coconut Oil on Your Hair and Skin\">Use Coconut Oil on Your Hair and Skin</a></li> \n  <li><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Hydrate-Hair\" title=\"Hydrate Hair\">Hydrate Hair</a></li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap\">\n  <ol class=\"references\"> \n   <li noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://www.webmd.com/beauty/hair-repair/natural-oils\">http://www.webmd.com/beauty/hair-repair/natural-oils</a></span> </li> \n   <li noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://www.diynatural.com/homemade-shampoo-with-jojoba-oil/\">http://www.diynatural.com/homemade-shampoo-with-jojoba-oil/</a></span> </li> \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 09 Mar 2022 16:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"f5ddbdd18c2a24aac6a32afac351d8ab","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn18@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-54-858_7167619dbe43cc22.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":85376,"destBytes":47456,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn18@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-54-858_7167619dbe43cc22.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn30@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-12-316_f559f6b9bc5fa5a4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn66@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-10-448_db1470a0309bee17.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn85@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-10-702_7c5ddbf19ddbe445.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn44@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-13-252_0d559479389483a0.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn31@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-14-098_c58235281439f7dd.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn56@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-13-581_82cee5d9ca54be71.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/21/Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid533103-v4-728px-Use-Jojoba-Oil-to-Enhance-Dry-Hair-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn82@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-11-098_d776fda56749bd8d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693947},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Make Ginger Ale","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Ginger-Ale","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\"><p>Even though you can look at the shelves in any supermarket and find various brands of ginger ale, making your own creates an entirely different (and remarkably better) taste. You can make a 2-liter bottle of fresh ginger ale straight from the ginger as long as you have the right ingredients.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Old-Fashioned Method\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Old-Fashioned-Method\">Old-Fashioned Method</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Gather your ingredients. Here's what you'll need to make ginger ale using the old-fashioned method:<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 1 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-1-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>1 cup (225 g) sugar</li>\n<li>2 tablespoons (30 g) <i>freshly</i> grated ginger root</li>\n<li>Juice of one lemon</li>\n<li>1/4 teaspoon (1.6 g) fresh granular baker's yeast</li>\n<li>Cold, pure water</li></ul></li>\n<li>Add 1 cup of sugar to a bottle through a dry funnel. Leave the funnel in place until all the steps are complete and you are ready to cap the bottle.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 2 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-2-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Measure out 1/4 teaspoon of fresh granular active baker's yeast. Use any brand that you might buy in the health food store.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 3 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-3-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Add the yeast through the funnel into the bottle. Shake the bottle to disperse the yeast grains into the sugar granules.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 4 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-4-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Grate the ginger root on a fine cutting grater to produce 2 tablespoons of grated root. Use the side of the grater with the finest teeth.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 5 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/32/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-5-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Place the grated ginger in a measuring cup.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 6 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-6-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Juice a whole lemon.  Lemon is important to keep the pH level low and ward off unwanted microorganisms. If you don't like lemon, try grapefruit juice instead.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 7 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-7-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Add the juice of a whole lemon to the grated ginger.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 8 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-8-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Stir the lemon juice and grated ginger to form a slurry, then add it to the bottle. It may stick in the funnel. Don't worry, the next steps will wash it into the bottle.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-9-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 9 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cf/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-9-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Rinse the container that held the lemon juice and grated ginger with fresh clean water. Add the rinsing water to the bottle.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 10 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-10-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Cap and shake the bottle. This helps activate the yeast and gets the carbonation process going.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 11 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/05/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-11-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Reopen and fill the bottle to the neck with fresh, cool, clean water. Leave about an inch of head space, then securely screw the cap down to seal. The head space is necessary to leave room for gasses that will be produced during fermentation. Invert the bottle repeatedly to thoroughly dissolve sugar.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-12-Version-4.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 12 Version 4.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-12-Version-4.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-12-Version-4.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Check the bottom of the bottle because the sugar tends to stick in little pockets there.  The ginger root will not dissolve, of course.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Place the ginger ale in a warm location for 24 to 48 hours. The warmth is necessary for the yeast to be able to ferment the brew. But don't forget about it! Too long and the alcohol concentration starts to increase and the taste changes greatly.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 13 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-13-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Test to see if carbonation is complete by squeezing the bottle forcefully with your thumb.  If it dents in as in the picture, it is not ready; the fermentation produces carbon dioxide (like in sodas and seltzers) that will inflate the bottle and make it difficult to squeeze.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 14 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-14-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Once the bottle feels hard to a forceful squeeze, usually after only 24-48 hours, place in the refrigerator. Refrigerate at least overnight to thoroughly chill before opening. Crack the lid off the cool ginger ale just a little to release the pressure slowly. You do not want a ginger ale fountain!<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-15-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 15 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4d/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-15-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-15-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: On The Stove-Top\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"On-The-Stove-Top\">On The Stove-Top</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Gather your ingredients. Here's what you'll need to make ginger ale using the stove-top method:<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-16-Version-3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 16 Version 3.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-16-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-16-Version-3.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>1 1/2 ounces finely grated fresh ginger</li>\n<li>3/4 c (6 ounces) sugar</li>\n<li>7 1/2 cups (60 ounces) filtered water</li>\n<li>1/8 teaspoon (.5 g) active dry yeast</li>\n<li>2 tablespoons (30 g) freshly squeezed lemon juice</li></ul></li>\n<li>Grab a large, 2-quart saucepan. Over medium-high heat, add the grated ginger, sugar, and 1/2 cup (4 oz) water together. Stir your concoction until the sugar has dissolved completely. This will take a few minutes, so be patient.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 17 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/df/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-17-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Once the sugar has dissolved, remove the pan from the heat. Place it to the side, cover and allow to steep for 1 hour. Resist the urge to mess with it -- right now your concoction needs uninterrupted time.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 18 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-18-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Strain your syrup. The easiest way to do this will be to pour the syrup through a fine mesh strainer set directly over the bowl. Press down on the bits to get all of the juice out of the mixture. Once you've got as much liquid out as possible, throw the bowl in an ice bath or set in the refrigerator until the concoction reaches room temperature -- 68 to 72°F (20 to 22°C).<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-19-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 19 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-19-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Get your funnel ready. Place it on top of a clean, plastic 2-liter bottle and pour in the syrup. Then, add the yeast, lemon juice and remaining 7 cups of water (56 oz). Twist the cap on the bottle until it's securely on and gently shake to mix everything together. Leave it alone and at room temperature for 48 hours.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-20-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 20 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-20-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>But no longer! If you leave it out too long, the taste will start to become too bitter as the yeast ferments.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Open 'er up. Pop open the top and check for the right amount of carbonation. If there seems to be enough, throw that baby in the fridge. If not, wait a little longer.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-21-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 21 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-21-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-21-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Store in the refrigerator for up to 2 weeks, opening the bottle at least once a day to let out excess carbonation. Otherwise pressure will build up and you risk it exploding.</li></ul></li></ol>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Non-Alcoholic Version\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Non-Alcoholic-Version\">Non-Alcoholic Version</span></h3>\n<ol><li>Gather your ingredients. Here's what you'll need to make non-alcoholic ginger ale:<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-22-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 22 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-22-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-22-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>1 cup (200 g) peeled, finely chopped ginger</li>\n<li>2 cups (450 ml) water</li>\n<li>1 cup (225 g) sugar</li>\n<li>1 cup (225 ml) water</li>\n<li>1/2 cup (115 ml) club soda (per glass)</li>\n<li>A few drops of lime juice</li>\n<li>Lime wedges (for garnish)</li></ul></li>\n<li>Bring 2 cups of water to a boil in a saucepan. Add the ginger, which should be peeled and finely chopped. Reduce heat to medium low and let the ginger sit in the simmering water for 5 minutes.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-23-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 23 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-23-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-23-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div>\n<ul><li>Remove from the heat and let sit for 20 minutes. Any longer than that and it might be <i>too</i> gingery.</li></ul></li>\n<li>Strain the liquid through a fine mesh strainer. Discard the ginger pieces. The water should be completely infused with the ginger taste, so you don't need them.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-24-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 24 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-24-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-24-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>In a separate saucepan, make the simple syrup. Dissolve 1 cup granulated sugar into 1 cup of boiling water. When it's not grainy anymore, it's ready. Set aside.<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-25-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 25 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-25-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-25-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li>\n<li>Mix 1/2 cup of ginger water with 1/3 cup of the simple syrup and 1/2 cup of club soda. This is the amount needed for each glass. Add a few drops of fresh lime juice and a lime wedge to each drink. Serve chilled and enjoy!<div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-26-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Ginger Ale Step 26 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-26-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-26-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a></div></li></ol>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2>\n<ul><li>Make sure the fermenting vessels are cleaned before use. There are a wide variety of powdered sanitizers that can be used.</li>\n<li>Fermentation has been used by mankind for thousands of years for raising bread, fermenting wine and brewing beer. Carbon dioxide causes bread to rise and gives effervescent drinks their bubbles. This action of yeast on sugar is used to carbonate beverages, as in the addition of bubbles to champagne.</li>\n<li>You may, of course, adjust the quantities of sugar and/or extract to taste. Note that the lemon called for in step seven is optional but recommended to discourage unwanted bacteria.  If you want a spicier drink, you can increase the amount of grated ginger.</li>\n<li>For an interesting variation, simmer a piece of well-bruised root ginger in water for an hour as an alternative method of extracting the flavor. This will give the water a golden/brownish tint. Start with about 20 g of ginger root per 2 litres of water and increase/decrease to taste.</li>\n<li>You can substitute artificial sweeteners for most of the sugar as long as you still use 2-3 tablespoons (28-42 grams) of real sugar; this is all that is actually required for the yeast to carbonate the beverage.</li>\n<li>Filter the ginger ale through a strainer if you find floating pieces of ginger objectionable.  (If you don't, these will pour out into the first glass or two and, since most of the ginger sinks to the bottom, again in the last glass or so.  Rinse the bottle out immediately after serving the last of the batch.</li>\n<li>To personalize your ginger ale, design your own label and attach it to the bottle as you place it with pride in the center of your dinner table.</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2>\n<ul><li>When purchasing your yeast, do not buy \"brewer's yeast,\" as this is typically inactive yeast left over from the brewing process.  It is dead yeast, and will not work.  For best results, buy yeast from a beer and wine maker's supply store.</li>\n<li><b>The first two recipes will produce alcohol in the finished product.</b> The quantity of alcohol in the finished product over a 2- to 3-day fermentation period is going to be minuscule; however, if left out for several days (see further warnings), it will continue to ferment until all of the sugar is gone, and the alcohol content will be considerably higher. It will taste nothing like ginger ale.  Note also that local laws pertaining to the production and consumption of alcoholic beverages may apply.  (For example, some \"dry\" areas maintain zero tolerance for alcohol in beverages.)</li>\n<li><b>Do not</b> leave the finished ginger ale in a warm place any longer than the time it takes for the bottle to feel hard. Leaving it at room temperature longer than two days, especially in the summer when the temperature is high, can generate enough pressure to <b>explode the bottle</b>! Once it is thoroughly chilled, there is little danger of it  exploding .</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Things You&#039;ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You'll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.27ll-Need\">Things You'll Need</span></h2>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Old-Fashioned Method\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Old-Fashioned-Method_2\">Old-Fashioned Method</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Clean 2-liter plastic soft drink bottle with cap</li>\n<li>Funnel</li>\n<li>Grater (preferably with fine \"cutting\" teeth)</li>\n<li>Measuring cup</li>\n<li>Measuring utensils</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=10\" title=\"Edit section: On the Stove-Top\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"On-the-Stove-Top_2\">On the Stove-Top</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Clean 2-liter plastic soft drink bottle with cap</li>\n<li>Funnel</li>\n<li>Grater (preferably with fine \"cutting\" teeth)</li>\n<li>Measuring cup</li>\n<li>Measuring utensils</li>\n<li>Strainer</li>\n<li>Saucepan</li></ul>\n<h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=11\" title=\"Edit section: Non-Alcoholic Version\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Non-Alcoholic-Version_2\">Non-Alcoholic Version</span></h3>\n<ul><li>Measuring cup</li>\n<li>Spoon</li>\n<li>Saucepan</li>\n<li>Strainer</li></ul>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Ginger-Ale&#38;action=edit&#38;section=12\" title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span
