Summary</span></h2>\n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 14 Mar 2022 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-1-Version-3.jpg","linkMd5":"16df0b0ceafe1b9e74fd833a0d7c55e7","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-56-563_130ce665a2fdc735.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":89474,"destBytes":62104,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-1-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-14-56-563_130ce665a2fdc735.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/83/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-2-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn70@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-10-576_242adbbc5cec70af.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-3-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/66/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-4-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn42@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-12-320_bd4c8602d3a28340.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/32/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-5-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn42@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-09-232_f46e053e076aa34d.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-6-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn37@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-11-032_4d49475a94edbdb5.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-7-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-7-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn35@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-13-481_d2b47391edf6bb59.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/eb/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-8-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn66@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-09-857_34f302391386d0f1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cf/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-9-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-9-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn75@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-10-012_a03e909495825406.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-10-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-10-Version-3.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/05/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-11-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-11-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn65@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-09-329_18f60a3d6a716dbc.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-12-Version-4.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-12-Version-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn9@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-20-445_c57e5c8a5879b143.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-13-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn21@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-09-556_256120bbefb057e6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a7/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-14-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-11-731_14b5eaea42dd6ce6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4d/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-15-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-15-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn64@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-13-757_c5f4333fa1b2efcb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bb/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-16-Version-3.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-16-Version-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn2@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-11-232_37e4823a6dc1591a.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/df/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-17-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn61@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-12-384_d33b396d5ca844cb.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-18-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn82@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-09-131_c08bd71549b6c14c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/96/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-19-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-19-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-20-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-20-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn5@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-27-228_2bd3e214df1459bf.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-21-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-21-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn96@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-10-348_3602433000997b54.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-22-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-22-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/99/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-23-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-23-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn90@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-10-708_ffbd85b0754a6ae8.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-24-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-24-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn11@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-09-797_e010de3344fb843e.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/26/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-25-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-25-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn49@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-12-496_c426e500c66c701f.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f5/Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-26-Version-2.jpg/aid82096-v4-728px-Make-Ginger-Ale-Step-26-Version-2.jpg":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693966},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Price Antiques and Collectibles","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Lots of people have interesting antiques and collectibles in their homes. Antiques are objects that are 100 years old or older, while collectibles are interesting objects that are less than 100 years old.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup> Maybe you’ve wondered how much that heavy old table your grandparents used to eat dinner at is worth. Or maybe you’ve sifted through your childhood toys and wondered what you could get for them. Trying to determine a good selling price can be tedious and drawn out or it can be quick, simple and even fun. The value of any antique or collectible is defined as what someone is willing to pay for the item on a given day. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Doing Your Homework\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Doing-Your-Homework\">Doing Your Homework</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Learn more about your item. It’s important to have a baseline of knowledge about the kind of item you want to sell. If you’re selling your grandparents’ old dining room table, it might be useful to find out what kind of table it is (style, material, and, if possible, who made it). You can find this kind of information in general reference books on antiques. <sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup> Most libraries have a section on guides for antiques and collectibles. <sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Once you identify your item and get a ballpark value, it will be easier for you to figure out a good price for that item.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Browse antique stores in your area. Look for items similar to the one you want to sell. Compare the condition of the items for sale to the condition of the one you have. Check for any differences in style, material, or maker. Then check how much the dealer is trying to sell the item for.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 2 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-2-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You might even want to talk to the dealer—ask about why they priced the item the way they did.</li> \n    <li>Beware: While antiques dealers can be helpful in determining a ballpark price for your item, you should ever ask them (or allow them) to appraise your item unless you know for sure that you will not sell your item to them. It is considered a conflict of interest for a dealer to appraise an item they intend to buy. If a dealer offers to buy an item after valuing it for you, say no. <sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Check online auction sites. Ebay, Amazon, and Craigslist are all useful sites for finding out how much people are willing to pay for items like yours. On Ebay, you can search for similar items which have recently been sold. This will help you to see what people are actually willing to pay for items like yours.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 3 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-3-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Keep in mind that these sites are highly competitive, so their prices tend to be on the low side. If you want to get the most money possible for your item, online auction sites aren’t the best gauge.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Check online price guides. Price guides list different types of antiques or collectibles along with a range of prices you can expect to get for them. Kovel’s is considered to be the best online guide for antiques and collectibles. You can get a free subscription or pay a yearly fee for its premium services. <sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 4 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-4-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Decide what kind of value you want to find out in your appraisal. Appraisers can give you several different kinds of price values, depending on how (or if) you want to sell your item.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 5 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-5-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Auction Value – The auction value is the amount that your item would be expected to sell for at an auction. Very rare or valuable items are often sold at auction because people are willing to spend more. However, items that are less rare or valuable tend to go for less at auction than they would at retail price, because there is not much demand for them.</li> \n    <li>Retail Value – Retail value is the amount of money your item would sell for in an antique store. If your item is not rare and you don’t expect its value to be high, the retail value is likely to be higher than the auction value. Remember, though, that an antique dealer will not buy your item from you at full retail value; if they did, they wouldn’t be able to make a profit.</li> \n    <li>Insurance Value – If you decide that you don’t want to sell your item, an appraiser can also assess its insurance value. This is the amount of money that you would need to replace your item in a “reasonable amount of time” if it is destroyed or stolen. This is useful is your item is especially valuable. <sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Don’t alter your item before you have it valued. Many people think that their item will be worth more if they clean it up before having it appraised. However, “restoring” or otherwise altering an item without talking to an expert first often has the effect of lowering the value of the item—sometimes by a lot. Keep your item just the way it is—flaws and all. <sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Using an Appraiser\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-an-Appraiser\">Using an Appraiser</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Hire a professional appraiser. It’s important that the person who appraises your item is a trustworthy professional. You don’t want to waste your money on an “appraiser” whose information is not correct.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup> It’s also important to hire a professional appraiser who is not also a dealer because they will not have a conflict of interest when appraising your item. <sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup> Here are some tips for picking the right appraiser:\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-7.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 7.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-7.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-7.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>A trustworthy appraiser will never offer to buy your item from you. If they do, kick them to the curb.</li> \n    <li>Never hire an appraiser who will charge you a percentage of the value of your item. A trustworthy appraiser will charge a flat or hourly fee for their services. This fee can be several hundred dollars.</li> \n    <li>Get references for trustworthy appraisers. Estate attorneys, antique dealers, and others who work with appraisers regularly are good resources for finding an appraiser. You can also find an appraiser through professional organizations like Appraisers Association of America, Inc. and the American Society of Appraisers.</li> \n    <li>Talk to several appraisers before choosing one. You’ll want to pick an appraiser who specializes in the kind of item you want to sell. Make sure to ask for a written estimate of the kind of fee the appraiser will charge and how long the appraisal will take. <sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Go to an auction house appraiser. Auction houses like Sotheby’s and Christie’s also offer appraisals. Sometimes—but not always—these appraisals are free. To find out when the auction houses near you are offering a free “valuation” or “appraisal day” to the public, check their websites. <sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-8.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 8.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-8.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-8.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Get a written report of your appraisal. A good appraiser will give you a written report that includes a detailed description of your item as well as a thorough outline of the steps the appraiser took in valuing your item. <sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup> It will also include the reasons for the appraisal and a list of who handled your item (if there was more than one person). The appraiser should give you an exact number for the item’s worth, rather than an estimate. <sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup> \n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-9.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 9.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-9.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-9.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Getting an Online Valuation\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Getting-an-Online-Valuation\">Getting an Online Valuation</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Find the right website. There are lots of websites where you can get your item appraised by a professional appraiser. Search for websites which specialize in the kind of item you are trying to sell. Lots of websites are geared toward very specific kinds of antiques or collectibles, from furniture to stamps to vintage toys.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-10.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 10.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-10.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-10.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Once you choose your appraiser, you will send them photos and descriptions of your item. Usually within about a week, the appraiser will send back an estimate of your item’s value. <sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup></li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Take good pictures of your item. Because online appraisers depend on photos to make their valuations, it’s important that the photos you send are high in quality. <sup id=\"_ref-15\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-15\">[15]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-11.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 11.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-11.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-11.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Send photos of the item from every angle. Include close-ups of any distinct details in your item. Make sure your photos are well-lit, in color, and not blurry.</li> \n    <li>Don’t hide any flaws in your item or misrepresent it. Don’t alter your photo to make your item look better than it does in person. Make sure to include photos of any damaged parts of your item, as well. Hiding or omitting flaws may get you a higher valuation for your item, but that value will not carry over when you try to sell it.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Be prepared to pay for your appraisal. The upside of using an online appraiser is that they are less expensive than in-person appraisers. Online appraisals vary in cost, but you can expect to pay at least $10-30. <sup id=\"_ref-16\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-16\">[16]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-12.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 12.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-12.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-12.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Take internet appraisals with a grain of salt. Because online appraisers don’t come in contact with your item, their appraisals cannot be as thorough as you’d get from an in-person appraisal. The best way to get an accurate appraisal of the value of your item is to hire an in-person appraiser. <sup id=\"_ref-17\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-17\">[17]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-13.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 13.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-13.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-13.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>It might be useful to get an online appraisal if you’re not sure whether your item is valuable enough to be worth paying an in-person appraiser.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Using a Price Guide\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Using-a-Price-Guide\">Using a Price Guide</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Look for price guides specializing in items like yours. A price guide is a book full of descriptions of specific types of items (antique furniture, baseball cards, stamps, etc.), along with the prices you can expect to get for each item. The best guide to use will depend on the kind of item you want to sell. <sup id=\"_ref-18\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 18\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-18\">[18]</a></sup> Kovel’s, in particular, is a highly respected publisher of price guides. <sup id=\"_ref-19\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-19\">[19]</a></sup> Many libraries have price guides on their shelves, too.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-14.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 14.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-14.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-14.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Choose the right price guide. Make sure that your price guide is up-to-date and recent. Because the prices of antiques and collectibles change depending on markets, an outdated price guide will not give you an accurate idea of how much your item is worth. <sup id=\"_ref-20\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 20\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-20\">[20]</a></sup>The best price guides will also include plenty of pictures of the items included in its pages.\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-15.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 15.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-15.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-15.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li> \n  <li>Take pricing from price guides with a grain of salt. The descriptions and values listed in price guides are general estimates. They cannot account for the wide variations in the quality and condition of specific items, economic conditions, or demand in specific regions. <sup id=\"_ref-21\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 21\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_note-21\">[21]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-16.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Price Antiques and Collectibles Step 16.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-16.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-16.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"546\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: References\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"References\">References</span></h2>\n <div class=\"mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns\">\n  <ol <li id=\"_note-5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_ref-5\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer id=\"_note-11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_ref-11\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_ref-12\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_ref-13\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://money.cnn.com/2002/06/03/pf/yourhome/q_appraise/\">http://money.cnn.com/2002/06/03/pf/yourhome/q_appraise/</a></span> </li> \n   <li </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-15\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_ref-15\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow id=\"_note-16\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_ref-16\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-17\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_ref-17\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" href=\"http://money.cnn.com/2002/06/03/pf/yourhome/q_appraise/\">http://money.cnn.com/2002/06/03/pf/yourhome/q_appraise/</a></span> </li> \n   <li </li> \n   <li id=\"_note-19\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles#_ref-19\">↑</a> <span class=\"reference-text\"><a target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noreferrer noopener\" class=\"external free\" \n  </ol>\n </div> \n</div>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 10 Mar 2022 00:00:00 +0000","feedId":44,"bgimg":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg","linkMd5":"a27f25fe5b2d0293107e02848e78cf30","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn4@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-14-55-084_2fadc6d4f353cec1.webp","destWidth":728,"destHeight":546,"sourceBytes":27732,"destBytes":17164,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b7/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-1-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn4@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-14-55-084_2fadc6d4f353cec1.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/78/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-2-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn72@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-13-905_34ed725082fbe286.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a8/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-3-Version-2.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-4-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn38@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-26-833_2b8c8337d165b1c6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-5-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn96@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-12-624_b31f2d7f7ca137e6.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d4/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-6-Version-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn78@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-10-265_177254d183a80729.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-7.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn58@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-11-438_a26271c162895d06.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-8.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn35@2020_3/2022/03/14/08-15-09-336_91cb1c416efb0fb9.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/70/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-9.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn97@2020_2/2022/03/14/08-15-27-535_74033274e56cc5c2.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c4/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-10.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-10.jpg":null,"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9a/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-11.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-11.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn68@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-13-914_c86527e5ce0cebe4.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e6/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-12.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn26@2020_6/2022/03/14/08-15-10-983_180e557ff283020b.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-13.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn10@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-10-246_5723a8d76e8d1e41.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-14.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn12@2020_5/2022/03/14/08-15-13-133_1c08336a6204885c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/43/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-15.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-15.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn17@2020_1/2022/03/14/08-15-09-263_3ef20c70672cfc5c.webp","https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-16.jpg/aid880027-v4-728px-Price-Antiques-and-Collectibles-Step-16.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn37@2020_4/2022/03/14/08-15-11-396_76cbf971ec42048a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1647245693948},{"createdTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","updatedTime":"2022-03-14 16:14:53","title":"How to Make Bean Soup","link":"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup","description":"<div class=\"mw-parser-output\">\n <p>Beans are a delicious, filling, and very cheap ingredient that work with almost any meal. If you’re heading into the colder seasons, there’s nothing that will warm you up quite like a big bowl of soup. By making a simple bean soup, and customizing it to your own tastes, you can have a delicious dish for any occasion. </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bean-Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1\" title=\"Edit section: Ingredients\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Ingredients\">Ingredients</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>of olive oil</li> \n  <li>2 onions</li> \n  <li>2 cloves of garlic</li> \n  <li>2 sticks of celery</li> \n  <li>1 tablespoon (17 g) of salt</li> \n  <li>1 tablespoon (6 g) of pepper</li> \n  <li>2 14-oz (400-g) cans of beans, such as black or cannellini beans</li> \n  <li>of liquid stock, like chicken or vegetable</li> \n  <li>2 red or green bell peppers (optional)</li> \n  <li>1 tablespoon (6 g) of thyme, rosemary, oregano, or cilantro (optional)</li> \n  <li>1 teaspoon (2 g) of chili powder or cayenne pepper (optional)</li> \n  <li>1 tablespoon (6 g) of smoked paprika (optional)</li> \n  <li>Shredded or diced meat, such as chicken, ham, or beef (optional)</li> \n  <li>of cream or milk (optional)</li> \n  <li>4 eggs (optional)</li> \n  <li>Fresh bread or tortillas (optional)</li>\n </ul> \n <p><i>Makes 4 servings</i> </p> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bean-Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2\" title=\"Edit section: Steps\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Steps\">Steps</span></h2> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bean-Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3\" title=\"Edit section: Sauteing the Vegetables\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Sauteing-the-Vegetables\">Sauteing the Vegetables</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Heat some olive oil in a large saucepan over a medium heat. Pour roughly of olive oil into a large saucepan and place it over a medium heat. Let the oil begin warming, to the point that it is easily moved around the bottom of the saucepan when tilted.<sup id=\"_ref-1\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 1\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-1\">[1]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bean-Soup-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bean Soup Step 1 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Make-Bean-Soup-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid6166214-v4-728px-Make-Bean-Soup-Step-1-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Any other cooking oil will work here, such as vegetable or canola, but it may not taste quite the same. If you don’t like the taste of olive oil, use an oil that you enjoy instead.</li> \n    <li>You can begin cutting up the vegetables in the next few steps while waiting for the oil to heat up, which should save on time.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Dice onions and garlic and add them to the pot. Place the 2 onions on a chopping board. Cut them in half lengthways, peel away the outer layers, and use a sharp knife to dice them finely. Peel and dice 2 cloves of garlic as well, and add them to the saucepan with the hot oil to begin sauteing.<sup id=\"_ref-2\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 2\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-2\">[2]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>There are plenty of different ways to <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-an-Onion\" title=\"Cut an Onion\">cut onion</a> and garlic. Choose an easy method that works for you.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Trim and slice 2 sticks of celery. Place 2 sticks of celery on a chopping board and slice in half lengthways. Line the celery sticks up and use a sharp knife to cut them into chunks that are roughly in width. Add the chopped celery to the pan with the onion, garlic, and oil.<sup id=\"_ref-3\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 3\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-3\">[3]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The celery will help add a little sweetness and freshness to the soup, but it can also be left out if you don’t like the taste.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Chop up some bell peppers for a spicier soup. If you like a little more heat or spiciness, you can add some bell peppers or capsicum to the soup. <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Cut-a-Bell-Pepper\" title=\"Cut a Bell Pepper\">Cut up a few bell peppers</a> into a rough, dice and add them to the saucepan to begin cooking.<sup id=\"_ref-4\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 4\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-4\">[4]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For a little more variety, use 1 green bell pepper and 1 red bell pepper, chopped in the same way.</li> \n    <li>If you want even more of a kick to your soup, try adding some finely diced chili peppers as well. Finely slice 1 fresh red chili pepper and add it to the saucepan with the other ingredients.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Mix in any other vegetables you want to. One of the great things about soup is how easy it is to customize and how difficult it is to mess up. Add any other vegetables you have in your kitchen to the soup, chopping them into roughly pieces before stirring them in.<br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Mushrooms, potatoes, carrots, and peas could all make great additions to this soup. Add whatever you have on hand and see how it tastes!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Cook the vegetables for 10 to 15 minutes, or until they are fragrant. Use a wooden spoon to stir the vegetables around in the pot as they cook to ensure they cook evenly. Let them saute for 10 to 15 minutes, or until the onion is translucent and all of the other vegetables become fragrant.<sup id=\"_ref-5\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 5\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-5\">[5]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bean-Soup-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bean Soup Step 6 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Make-Bean-Soup-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid6166214-v4-728px-Make-Bean-Soup-Step-6-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>While they will cook further as the soup cooks, sauteing the vegetables first will make the whole dish taste much better. If you’re particularly short on time, you can throw them into the saucepan with all the other ingredients to cook.</li> \n    <li>The vegetables should be vibrant colors and just beginning to soften after around 10 to 15 minutes. These signs, along with the more fragrant aroma of the vegetables, are a good sign that they are ready.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add salt, pepper, and any other seasonings you like. As with any dish, you should season it with salt and pepper as you cook. Sprinkle over roughly 1 tablespoon (17 g) of salt and 1 tablespoon (6 g) of black pepper and stir to combine. If you want to add any other flavors or seasonings to the soup, mix them in now.<sup id=\"_ref-6\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 6\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-6\">[6]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For a little aromatic freshness, try mixing in 1 tablespoon (6 g) of thyme, rosemary, oregano, or cilantro.</li> \n    <li>If you want a little extra spiciness, add in 1 teaspoon (2 g) of chili powder or cayenne pepper.</li> \n    <li>For a slightly smoky flavor in your soup, mix in 1 tablespoon (6 g) of smoked paprika.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bean-Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4\" title=\"Edit section: Cooking the Beans\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Cooking-the-Beans\">Cooking the Beans</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Pour 2 cans of tinned beans into the saucepan. You can use almost any type of bean that you like or just that you have on hand for a bean soup. Pour 2 14-oz (40- g) cans of black, kidney, cannellini, or whatever other types of canned bean you have into the saucepan and stir to combine.<sup id=\"_ref-7\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 7\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-7\">[7]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>You can also use dried beans that have soaked first instead. Boil 1 cup (225 g) of dried beans in enough water to cover them for around 2 minutes, before leaving them to soak for around 1 hour.</li> \n    <li>Use whichever type of bean you like the most, or whichever one you have the easiest access to.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add of stock to the pot. The stock will help build some of the flavors of the soup, as well as giving the beans something more to cook in. Add around of whatever stock you have on hand or that you enjoy. Chicken and vegetable stock will both work excellently, but you can easily use beef stock or even just water instead.<sup id=\"_ref-8\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 8\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-8\">[8]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>For a slightly more complex flavor in your finished soup, try adding different types of stock. Use each of chicken and vegetable stock, or any other combination you like. Soup is easy to customize and very difficult to mess up, so see what flavors you can come up with to complement the beans!</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Stir in some diced ham or bacon for a meatier soup. If you want some extra protein or flavor in your soup, roughly chop up some ham, fried bacon, cooked sausage, or whatever other meat you have available. Scatter over the top of your soup and mix it in.<sup id=\"_ref-9\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 9\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-9\">[9]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>This is another great point to customize your soup to your own preferences. Leftover chicken, beef, lamb, ham, meatballs, and anything else can add some more flavor to the soup.</li> \n    <li>Use roughly 1 cup (125 g to 175 g) of whatever diced meat you choose to use. You can add more or less depending on how meaty you want your soup to be.</li> \n    <li>If you’re a vegetarian or vegan, or you simply don’t want to add meat to your soup, feel free to skip this step.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Bring the soup to a simmer and cook for 40 minutes. Give the soup a good final stir to make sure all of the ingredients are well incorporated and combined. Reduce the heat to low and bring the soup to a simmer. Cover it and leave it to simmer for around 40 minutes, giving it time to thicken up and cook the beans.<sup id=\"_ref-10\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 10\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-10\">[10]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you want a thicker soup, remove the lid after 40 minutes and let it simmer for a further 10 minutes. This will let more liquid cook off and result in a thicker, heartier soup.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h3><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bean-Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5\" title=\"Edit section: Finishing the Soup\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Finishing-the-Soup\">Finishing the Soup</span></h3> \n <ol>\n  <li>Blend the soup to your desired consistency. Once you’ve given the soup enough time to simmer and cook, take it off the heat. Use a hand or stick blender to begin processing the soup and blending some of the beans and other ingredients. This will make it creamier and a little smoother.<sup id=\"_ref-11\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 11\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-11\">[11]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>The more you blend your soup, the thicker and smoother it will be. For a thinner soup with more chunks, blend the soup for only a few seconds. Alternately, you can avoid blending it at all for a very thin and chunky soup.</li> \n    <li>If you prefer your soup to be thick and very smooth, blend it until all of the beans have been processed and the soup reaches a creamier consistency.</li> \n    <li>If you don’t have a hand or stick blender, you can pour your soup in the jug of a standard kitchen blender to process it slightly. You may need to work in batches depending on the size of your blender.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Add some milk or cream for some extra richness. If you want your soup to be a little richer or creamier, measure out roughly of milk or cream and pour into the simmered soup. Mix it thoroughly to combine for a slightly smoother and richer soup.<sup id=\"_ref-12\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 12\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-12\">[12]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>If you want to keep this recipe vegan, you can skip this step entirely.</li> \n    <li>You could also use the same amount of sour cream or yogurt for extra thickness and creaminess. However, this will also impart the flavor of your chosen yogurt or sour cream into the soup. If you don't like the taste of sour cream, yogurt, milk, or cream, then leave them out of this dish.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Poach some eggs in the soup for some extra protein. Once you’ve blended the soup to your desired consistency, place it back over a medium heat and bring it to a simmer. Break 4 eggs into the soup so that they are spread apart and just submerged. Leave the eggs to cook, uncovered, for 5 minutes or until the whites are cooked and the yolks are runny.<sup id=\"_ref-13\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 13\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-13\">[13]</a></sup><br /><br /> \n   <ul>\n    <li>When serving, fill a bowl with soup and place the poached eggs onto it last. When you pierce the yolk, it will run across the soup, both looking and tasting incredible.</li> \n    <li>Break the eggs, one at a time, into a small bowl first. Use the bowl to pour the eggs carefully into the soup. This will help keep the eggs together as you transfer them to the saucepan.</li>\n   </ul></li> \n  <li>Serve the soup with some fresh bread or warmed tortillas. Spoon the soup into a large bowl while it is still hot to serve. Eat it alongside some freshly cooked or lightly toasted bread, or opt for some tortillas that have been warmed through as an accompaniment.<sup id=\"_ref-14\" class=\"reference\" aria-label=\"Link to Reference 14\"><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Make-Bean-Soup#_note-14\">[14]</a></sup>\n   <div class=\"mwimg  largeimage  floatcenter \" style=\"max-width:728px\">\n    <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/Image:Make-Bean-Soup-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"Make Bean Soup Step 15 Version 2.jpg\" src=\"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/95/Make-Bean-Soup-Step-15-Version-2.jpg/aid6166214-v4-728px-Make-Bean-Soup-Step-15-Version-2.jpg\" decoding=\"async\" width=\"728\" height=\"410\" class=\"whcdn\" /></a>\n   </div> \n   <ul>\n    <li>Once cooked, you can store the soup in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 3 days.</li>\n   </ul></li>\n </ol> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bean-Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6\" title=\"Edit section: Video\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Video\">Video</span></h2> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bean-Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7\" title=\"Edit section: Tips\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Tips\">Tips</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Soup is easily customizable to whatever flavors you like. Use whatever beans, stock, vegetables, or flavorings you enjoy to make this soup perfect for you.</li> \n  <li>If you leave the soup to simmer for too long and it becomes too thick, you can thin it slightly with milk, cream, water, or some more of your chosen stock.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bean-Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8\" title=\"Edit section: Warnings\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Warnings\">Warnings</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Use oven mitts or a dry tea towel to handle the pot once the soup has simmered, as it will be very hot.</li> \n  <li>If you add chili peppers to the soup, make sure you wear gloves while handling them or wash your hands thoroughly afterward.</li> \n  <li>Be careful when lifting the lid off of the simmered soup, as built up steam may escape quickly. Never stand over the pot as you take the lid off.</li>\n </ul> \n <h2><span class=\"mw-editsection\"><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">[</span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.wikihow.com/index.php?title=Make-Bean-Soup&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9\" title=\"Edit section: Things You’ll Need\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span id=\"Things-You’ll-Need\"></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Things-You.E2.80.99ll-Need\">Things You’ll Need</span></h2> \n <ul>\n  <li>Large saucepan with lid</li> \n  <li>Stovetop or hotplate</li> \n  <li>Cutting board</li> \n  <li>Knife</li> \n  <li>Wooden spoon</li> \n  <li>Hand blender, stick blender, or kitchen blender</li>\n </ul> \n title=\"Edit section: Related wikiHows\">Edit</a><span class=\"mw-editsection-bracket\">]</span></span><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Related-wikiHows\">Related wikiHows</span></h2> \n <ul>\n
